2017-08-17.abstract: How the shoot and story came together with the enigmatic Japanese designer of Undercover.
2017-08-17.snippet: How the shoot and story came together with the enigmatic Japanese designer of Undercover.
2017-08-17.lead_paragraph: After scouting numerous locations around Tokyo — Kabuki theaters, sumo wrestling pits, even Shibuya crossing — the T team eventually chose two historical Japanese teahouses inside the Tokyo National Museum for the site of its shoot on Jun Takahashi of Undercover. The teahouses, which are both closed to the public, and the surrounding Ueno Park, provided an ideal backdrop for the sculptural, fantastical pieces from the designer’s fall 2017 collection. As Patrick Li, T’s creative director, put it, the structures provided a contrast — of a traditional Japanese setting for “Jun’s directional, futuristic viewpoint.”
2017-08-17.headline_main: Inside Jun Takahashi’s World — and Studio

2017-08-17.abstract: His rich baritone has been called the voice of choice for more than 1,300 pieces of literature, including “Crime and Punishment,” “The Corrections” and plenty of Stephen King.
2017-08-17.snippet: His rich baritone has been called the voice of choice for more than 1,300 pieces of literature, including “Crime and Punishment,” “The Corrections” and plenty of Stephen King.
2017-08-17.lead_paragraph: Early in his career as a narrator of audiobooks, George Guidall received a note from a truck driver in Montana. The man had been so absorbed in listening to Mr. Guidall’s eloquent recording of “Crime and Punishment” that he drove off the road. He was writing from his hospital bed to thank Mr. Guidall because he now had time to finish listening to the book.
2017-08-17.headline_main: Why George Guidall Is the Undisputed King of Audiobooks

2017-08-17.abstract: Many celebrities are in on the audiobook business. Here, readings from more than 20 of them.
2017-08-17.snippet: Many celebrities are in on the audiobook business. Here, readings from more than 20 of them.
2017-08-17.lead_paragraph: Audiobooks provide thriving ancillary careers for some of film’s boldest-faced names — no makeup or costumes required. Meryl Streep seems to have the perfect pitch for children’s favorites, including “The Velveteen Rabbit” and Beatrix Potter’s “The Tailor of Gloucester.” Samuel L. Jackson has helped intone much of the Bible. Lena Dunham, Martha Stewart and RuPaul all chimed in on Sheila Nevins’s “You Don’t Look Your Age…and Other Fairy Tales.”
2017-08-17.headline_main: Hollywood on Tape

2017-08-17.abstract: The first New York showing of all 57 illustrations that Maira Kalman dared to make for “The Elements of Style,” the primer on writing well.
2017-08-17.snippet: The first New York showing of all 57 illustrations that Maira Kalman dared to make for “The Elements of Style,” the primer on writing well.
2017-08-17.lead_paragraph: Around 2002, the artist, illustrator and writer Maira Kalman came across a copy of William Strunk Jr. and E. B. White’s “The Elements of Style” in a yard sale and decided that this legendary if sometimes contested guide to grammar and clear writing needed visual accompaniment. So she provided some, making 57 illustrations inspired by sentences and phrases selected from the book. All these images Ms. Kalman rendered in gouache in a delectably colored figurative style indebted to David Hockney and Florine Stettheimer. They were then sprinkled throughout a 2005 version of “Elements” based on its fourth edition, covered in exuberant red. Now all Ms. Kalman’s illustrations can be seen — together for the first time in New York — in a smart, beguiling array at the Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea.
2017-08-17.headline_main: Maira Kalman’s Irreverent Pictures for the Grammar Bible

2017-08-17.abstract: The architects Marion Weiss and Michael Manfredi display maps, photographs and an Italian flavor on their apartment walls.
2017-08-17.snippet: The architects Marion Weiss and Michael Manfredi display maps, photographs and an Italian flavor on their apartment walls.

2017-08-17.abstract: Two black sisters were admiring a counterdemonstration — “so many white people, more than our race,” one said — when a car drove into the crowd and smashed into their Camry.
2017-08-17.snippet: Two black sisters were admiring a counterdemonstration — “so many white people, more than our race,” one said — when a car drove into the crowd and smashed into their Camry.
2017-08-17.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Tadrint R. Washington is not one to attend protests. So when she and her sister, heading home from a friend’s house in a 2005 Toyota Camry, neared the site of a white supremacy rally last Saturday, she was stunned. She saw a sea of white faces. But they were chanting, “Black lives matter.”
2017-08-17.headline_main: Rammed by Car in Charlottesville, but Seeing a Sign of Hope

Haley, on Thursday urged the organization to go beyond its inquiry into the killings of two investigators in the Democratic Republic of Congo, saying that the U.N. report amounted to only a “first step” in tracking down those responsible.

2017-08-17.abstract: With its long history and shifting borders, and a bloody century marked by two World Wars, fights over public statues are nothing new in Europe.
2017-08-17.snippet: With its long history and shifting borders, and a bloody century marked by two World Wars, fights over public statues are nothing new in Europe.
2017-08-17.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Recent episodes of rage and bloodshed over the removal of Confederate statues in the United States have a familiar ring for Europeans, who have been battling over their historical narratives and tearing down statues of noxious former leaders since the Bronze Age — and probably before.

2017-08-18.snippet: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 18, 2017.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: “Those who died in Bulacan, 32, in a massive raid, that’s good. If we can kill another 32 every day, then maybe we can reduce what ails this country.”

2017-08-18.abstract: With the Islamic State leaving behind thickets of booby traps and improvised explosive devices, the Pentagon seeks to help clear its own remnants of war.

2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Pentagon is seeking to declassify strike targets in Mosul where American bombs did not explode, Defense Department officials say. That information would be used as part of a long and potentially dangerous effort to make the city, the site of eight months of fierce fighting between the Islamic State and an American-led coalition, livable again.

2017-08-18.abstract: Austin, who homered along with Aaron Judge in their debuts last August, has battled an injury bug that has also struck other Yankees first basemen.
2017-08-18.snippet: Austin, who homered along with Aaron Judge in their debuts last August, has battled an injury bug that has also struck other Yankees first basemen.

Then, one batter later, Aaron Judge, also making his debut in the majors, does the same thing.

Most of these deaths are caused by opioids like prescription painkillers, heroin and the potent synthetic drug fentanyl.

Put your hands above your heads and wave them slowly. Avoid reacting to a confrontation in a way that makes you look like prey: no screaming, flailing or running.

2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: A parenthetical sentence is a paradoxical thing. It straddles worlds: It is both inside and outside the text simultaneously, included and excluded. It is not quite important enough to merit the full center-stage spotlight but also not unimportant enough to be shoved entirely behind a curtain. A pair of parentheses is the sound of a text leaning over and whispering to us.
2017-08-18.headline_main: New Sentences: From ‘The Great Nadar,’ by Adam Begley

2017-08-18.abstract: The terrifying beauty of totality is best confronted in a crowd.
2017-08-18.snippet: The terrifying beauty of totality is best confronted in a crowd.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: In March 2006, I stood on a crowded beach in Turkey and waited until, at the allotted time, with a chorus of screams and cheers and whistles and applause, the sun slid away, and impossibly, impossibly, we saw above us a stretch of black sky and in the middle of it a hole, blacker than anything I’d ever seen, fringed with a ring of soft white fire. My heart jumped up to my throat, and my eyes grew hot with tears. I fell to my knees, feeling tiny and huge, and as lonely as I’ve ever been, but also astonishingly close to the crowds around me.
2017-08-18.headline_main: How to Stay Sane During a Solar Eclipse

2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: PALMER, Alaska — For years, pet owners in this Anchorage suburb of big homes and lawns have fretted over snares set in the local parks by fur-trappers going after fox, lynx and rabbits. But in a quiet revolution this spring, dog lovers got the upper hand, and after a series of public meetings where few trappers showed up to fight back, trapping was banned by the borough council. The suburbs had won.

2017-08-18.abstract: Allan Dunlap was among 800,000 Wells Fargo borrowers wrongly charged for auto coverage. The bank admits errors, but he’s had to fight to be made whole.
2017-08-18.snippet: Allan Dunlap was among 800,000 Wells Fargo borrowers wrongly charged for auto coverage. The bank admits errors, but he’s had to fight to be made whole.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has promised to make amends to the customers it forced to buy car insurance that they didn’t need. Allan Dunlap, a former Wells Fargo borrower who spent months trying to get the bank to correct an insurance error that marred his credit report, says he’ll believe it when he sees it.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Wells Fargo Borrower Got Unneeded Insurance, and Ruined Credit

2017-08-18.abstract: In three new thrillers the search is on: for a missing best friend, a possibly dead mom and a really angry stalker.
2017-08-18.snippet: In three new thrillers the search is on: for a missing best friend, a possibly dead mom and a really angry stalker.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: LOCAL GIRL MISSING By Claire Douglas 340 pp. Harper, paper, $15.99.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Disappearing Acts: Thrillers Stalk Women With Deadly Secrets

2017-08-18.abstract: Tasting rooms without attitude, wine-friendly menus and fields of wheat and spearmint are among the many charms of this region of Washington State.
2017-08-18.snippet: Tasting rooms without attitude, wine-friendly menus and fields of wheat and spearmint are among the many charms of this region of Washington State.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Travelers to the Pacific Northwest are sometimes lured by postcard promises of orca whales or the Space Needle against a backdrop of lofty peaks. But what too few tourists learn is this: The massive dome of Mount Rainier — arguably the showiest of Washington State’s majestic Cascades — is best beheld not from Puget Sound but from the high desert east of the mountains. There, from points up and down the Yakima Valley, Rainier and its sister summit, Mount Adams, loom like giant snow cones above swaths of irrigated farmland and sagebrush-covered range.
2017-08-18.headline_main: In the Yakima Valley, Serious Wines and Sweeping Vistas

2017-08-18.abstract: Despite all its problems, there is plenty to appreciate about air travel, from its technology and safety to its history and entertaining in-flight videos.
2017-08-18.snippet: Despite all its problems, there is plenty to appreciate about air travel, from its technology and safety to its history and entertaining in-flight videos.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Between getting dragged off a plane, punched in the face and paying five times what you normally would for a small can of Pringles, passengers have good reasons to be grumpy. But with National Aviation Day taking place on Aug. 19, why not take a day off from ranting on Twitter to appreciate some of the positive aspects of air travel? There is plenty to marvel at, from its technology and safety to its fascinating history and entertaining in-flight videos.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Appreciating Air Travel (For One Day, At Least)

2017-08-18.abstract: While his Long Island community grieves, experts question the safety of a practice drill that led to the death of a high school student.
2017-08-18.snippet: While his Long Island community grieves, experts question the safety of a practice drill that led to the death of a high school student.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: FARMINGVILLE, N.Y. — It was the first official day of football season at Sachem High School East here, but the field remained empty and silent. The overcast sky bore down on the green grounds; dreary weather on a dreadful day. If not for the accident, Joshua Mileto’s team would have been holding tryouts for the new season.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Sorrow and Scrutiny After a Teenager’s Death at Football Practice

2017-08-18.abstract: A house by Frank Lloyd Wright is instantly recognizable, but what does it take to market, sell or even live in something designed by him.
2017-08-18.snippet: A house by Frank Lloyd Wright is instantly recognizable, but what does it take to market, sell or even live in something designed by him.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: In mid-September, Frank Lloyd Wright aficionados are expected by the busload in New Canaan, Conn., passing through a gate with the name “Tirranna” carved into the metalwork, to tour a 6,917-square-foot hemicycle house largely designed by America’s master architect.
2017-08-18.headline_main: How to Sell a Frank Lloyd Wright House

2017-08-18.abstract: I bonded with my mother while making clothes. Now I bond with my daughter while disposing of them.
2017-08-18.snippet: I bonded with my mother while making clothes. Now I bond with my daughter while disposing of them.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: When summer winds down and my teenage daughter gets ready to start the new school year, she and I go through a ritual. I open her closet and take things out. She wrinkles her nose, rolls her eyes and ignores me, her eyes firmly glued to a screen. I pile clothes on her bed, taking them off hangers or rescuing them from drawers filled to such capacity that opening them is a challenge. She takes her eyes off Instagram for a moment, and says:
2017-08-18.headline_main: Back-to-School Clothes, Back in the U.S.S.R.

2017-08-18.abstract: “This is not the typical New Orleans experience,” Mr. Lagasse said. “Meril is how I think people want to eat today.”
2017-08-18.snippet: “This is not the typical New Orleans experience,” Mr. Lagasse said. “Meril is how I think people want to eat today.”
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Even with three successful restaurants in New Orleans, Emeril Lagasse knew that there was room for a new addition to the city’s ebullient dining scene. Emeril’s New Orleans has long cultivated contemporary food in the city, while Emeril’s Delmonico offers a fresh take on Creole cuisine and NOLA Restaurant presents a taste of Acadiana, with a global tinge. Meril, which Mr. Lagasse named after his youngest daughter and opened in the Warehouse District in September 2016, is the newest star in his constellation.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Meril, From Emeril Lagasse, Looks Beyond New Orleans for Inspiration

2017-08-18.abstract: American travelers should consider Guam for its history, its beauty and its barbecue.
2017-08-18.snippet: American travelers should consider Guam for its history, its beauty and its barbecue.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: On a nub-like point on the west coast of Guam stands a monument built as the Statue of Liberty’s Pacific counterpart. The Latte of Freedom, which opened in 2010, is an 80-foot-tall concrete structure, shaped like a mushroom with an upturned top. It’s a homage to the island’s famous lattes (pronounced LAH-tees), two-piece stone pillars that, for centuries, the indigenous Chamorros erected as the foundation of traditional buildings. In the observation deck inside the Latte of Freedom’s capstone, a plaque explains its cultural roots and announces its modern-day purpose: “to stand boldly as America’s Western gatepost from Asia and the Pacific Rim.”
2017-08-18.headline_main: Guam Is Suddenly in the News. But What Is It Like to Travel There?

2017-08-18.abstract: After suicidal thoughts put an Episcopal-priest-to-be into the hospital, a fellow seminarian came to realize how much he loved her.
2017-08-18.snippet: After suicidal thoughts put an Episcopal-priest-to-be into the hospital, a fellow seminarian came to realize how much he loved her.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: From the moment he spotted her in a church pew in 2012, Noah Sutter had a crush on Anna Risch, a college student with part of Psalm 18 (“I stood there saved, surprised to be loved”) tattooed on her forearm. But it was the Anna Risch he got to know two years later — the one whose suicidal thoughts had put her into a hospital — whom he fell in love with.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Coping With Depression as Love Wins the Day

2017-08-18.snippet: New York is becoming a cultural center for young women trying to disrupt the male-dominated industries of design engineering and sex toys.

2017-08-18.headline_main: Women of Sex Tech, Unite

He is one of a few world leaders who rarely criticize or even comment on Mr. Trump’s political turmoil at home.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Japan Still Seeks U.S. Protection but Quietly Stakes Its Own Path

2017-08-18.abstract: A coming installment of the group’s series at Riverside Church features the harpist Jacqueline Kerrod, and works by John Luther Adams and Adrienne Albert.
2017-08-18.snippet: A coming installment of the group’s series at Riverside Church features the harpist Jacqueline Kerrod, and works by John Luther Adams and Adrienne Albert.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: From their perch high up in the tower of Riverside Church, the Locrian Chamber Players continue to present one of the most consistently interesting new-music series — and when they say new, they mean it: Only works written in the past 10 years make the cut. On Friday, Aug. 25, regular members of the ensemble will be joined by the harpist Jacqueline Kerrod for an evening of musical reveries and meditations.
2017-08-18.headline_main: The Locrian Chamber Players Put ‘New Music’ on the Manhattan Map

2017-08-18.abstract: On the wings of his Netflix comedy special, “Staying Alive,” Mr. Morgan closes a stint at the comedy club with more of his near-death experience quipping.
2017-08-18.snippet: On the wings of his Netflix comedy special, “Staying Alive,” Mr. Morgan closes a stint at the comedy club with more of his near-death experience quipping.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: At the start of his recent Netflix special, “Staying Alive,” Tracy Morgan doesn’t waste any time addressing his near-death experience, when a car he was in collided with a Wal-Mart truck; he broke his nose, a leg and ribs in the crash and sustained a traumatic brain injury. “Could have been worse,” he said. “I could’ve got hit by a Bob’s Discount Furniture truck.” Recovering from the 2014 accident, with a healthy settlement, he has not only emerged every bit as strong as a comic, but he’s also incorporated the experience into his act.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Tracy Morgan’s Post-Crash Comedy Comes to Caroline’s

2017-08-18.abstract: The Harlem rapper, scheduled to perform in Manhattan on Wednesday, is back outside of the system.
2017-08-18.snippet: The Harlem rapper, scheduled to perform in Manhattan on Wednesday, is back outside of the system.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: It wasn’t supposed to go like this for the ostracized Harlem rapper Azealia Banks. After “212,” her 2011 viral hit that still sounds like it came from the future, Ms. Banks was strapped to the industry rocket ship — a major-label record deal, magazine covers, a Pharrell collaboration — only to self-destruct. With her strong will and studiously uncouth opinions (including a trollish Trump endorsement), she became better known as a social-media loose cannon than a musician.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Azealia Banks Eyes a Comeback and a Homecoming

2017-08-18.abstract: The visual artist and her friend, the choreographer John Heginbotham, have collaborated on an absurd travelogue incorporating dancers and complex sets.
2017-08-18.snippet: The visual artist and her friend, the choreographer John Heginbotham, have collaborated on an absurd travelogue incorporating dancers and complex sets.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Take a walk. Who knows what you’ll find? One observant and serendipitous walker through the world is the artist Maira Kalman, whose fanciful drawings have graced children’s books, covers for The New Yorker and the pages of many other publications, including The New York Times. She and her friend John Heginbotham — a former member of the Mark Morris Dance Group who now directs his own troupe, Dance Heginbotham — have collaborated on “The Principles of Uncertainty.”
2017-08-18.headline_main: Maira Kalman and ‘The Principles of Uncertainty’ Head to Jacob’s Pillow

2017-08-18.abstract: The artist J.P.W.3’s exhibition also includes a wall of ribbons and a pro shop that sells custom-designed tennis gear, featuring Ms. Williams.
2017-08-18.snippet: The artist J.P.W.3’s exhibition also includes a wall of ribbons and a pro shop that sells custom-designed tennis gear, featuring Ms. Williams.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: The artist JPW3 (J. Patrick Walsh) has described his materials — wax, tuning forks, car engines, doorways, popcorn — as “an excess of fuel,” which he directs toward his various experiments in painting, installation, performance and holography. Now, in a show called “Figure Ascending a Return,” which opened Aug. 17 at Martos Gallery’s new Elizabeth Street location, he has created another version of his Serena Williams hologram, “Serena Hologram xl, 2017.”
2017-08-18.headline_main: A New Hologram of Serena Williams at Martos Gallery

2017-08-18.abstract: On Aug. 21, when a coast-to-coast total solar eclipse crossed the United States, PBS will provide a companion show.
2017-08-18.snippet: On Aug. 21, when a coast-to-coast total solar eclipse crossed the United States, PBS will provide a companion show.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: For those stuck under a rock on Aug. 21 when the Eclipse Across America plunges moongazers along the narrow “path of totality” into darkness (and the rest of us into various shades of dim), “Nova” is coming to the rescue. That evening, the PBS science show will present a companion to this celestial experience — the first time since June 8, 1918, that a coast-to-coast total solar eclipse has occurred in North America — featuring footage shot earlier in the day by NASA and local public television stations in the path.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Ready for the Solar Eclipse? ‘Nova’ on PBS Has You Covered

2017-08-18.abstract: Nitehawk Cinema in Brooklyn and the IFC Center in Greenwich Village are offering films into the wee hours.

2017-08-18.abstract: New developments are adding crunchy lifestyle concepts like apiaries, composters and communal kitchens, but they’re part of a luxury package.
2017-08-18.snippet: New developments are adding crunchy lifestyle concepts like apiaries, composters and communal kitchens, but they’re part of a luxury package.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: As dusk fell over Staten Island on a recent evening, about 10 people sat around a large wooden table in a communal kitchen, listening to Van Morrison and painting terra-cotta flowerpots. Houseplants were suspended from the room’s high wood-beamed ceilings, and the smell of freshly baked bread hung in the air.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Hippie Amenities With a High-End Twist

2017-08-18.abstract: Mr. Strahan is enjoying his last few idle Sundays — strolling in Central Park and driving in New Jersey — before he resumes his gig with “Fox N.F.L. Sunday.”
2017-08-18.snippet: Mr. Strahan is enjoying his last few idle Sundays — strolling in Central Park and driving in New Jersey — before he resumes his gig with “Fox N.F.L. Sunday.”
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Michael Strahan, the Hall of Fame defensive end who played 15 seasons with the New York Giants before retiring in 2008 after helping the team win the Super Bowl, probably changed a lot of Sundays for a lot of people. These days, however, Sundays tend to change him. Now a sought-after television host, Mr. Strahan, 45, who is currently appearing on both ABC’s “Good Morning America” and “The $100,000 Pyramid,” has a chance to catch his breath on the weekends. That will soon change, however, when he returns to his third gig, “Fox N.F.L. Sunday,” in September. Mr. Strahan lives in a townhouse on the Upper West Side.
2017-08-18.headline_main: How Michael Strahan, Television Host, Spends His Sundays

2017-08-18.abstract: The horror has shown how thin the line is that divides civility from barbarism.
2017-08-18.snippet: The horror has shown how thin the line is that divides civility from barbarism.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: It was painful, conspicuous and easy: the sort of target terrorists are always looking for. Las Ramblas of Barcelona, Spain, where two men crashed a van Thursday into unsuspecting bystanders, killing at least 13 people and wounding more than 100, is a wide, unprotected, mile-long pedestrian artery. It stretches from the busy urban center to the old seaport.
2017-08-18.headline_main: When Terror Came to Barcelona

2017-08-18.abstract: Susan Bro, the mother of Heather Heyer, had a message for the president: “Think before you speak.”
2017-08-18.snippet: Susan Bro, the mother of Heather Heyer, had a message for the president: “Think before you speak.”

2017-08-18.abstract: Markus Hinterhäuser trades his piano bench for an impresario’s chair at one of classical music’s grandest, and most important, festivals.
2017-08-18.snippet: Markus Hinterhäuser trades his piano bench for an impresario’s chair at one of classical music’s grandest, and most important, festivals.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — The last time Markus Hinterhäuser worked with the South African artist William Kentridge and the German baritone Matthias Goerne, he was the accompanist — bringing his intense, sensitive piano playing to their multimedia production of Schubert’s “Winterreise” song cycle, which won wide praise and went on to tour the world.
2017-08-18.headline_main: A Pianist With Modern Flair Takes Over the Salzburg Festival

2017-08-18.abstract: The current crisis fits a historical pattern of racial disparity in how society treats drug users.
2017-08-18.snippet: The current crisis fits a historical pattern of racial disparity in how society treats drug users.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Every Friday evening, with sadness and with pride, I make a 90-minute trek from Columbia University to Sing Sing Correctional Facility to teach a drugs and behavior course. My students, who are bright and predominantly black, enthusiastically engage with the curriculum, not least because some of them have a personal stake in the subject. Several are serving time for a drug-related offense, as are hundreds of thousands of other Americans.
2017-08-18.headline_main: The Real Opioid Emergency

2017-08-18.abstract: Tempted to grab that once-in-a-lifetime eclipse snapshot? Feel free: Taking pictures helps people engage with and remember experiences more deeply, according to new research.
2017-08-18.snippet: Tempted to grab that once-in-a-lifetime eclipse snapshot? Feel free: Taking pictures helps people engage with and remember experiences more deeply, according to new research.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: On Monday, I will be one of millions watching the moon punch a hole in the sun during the Great American Eclipse of 2017. In preparation, I’ve been thinking about how I want to spend my roughly two minutes of totality, when day surrenders, briefly, to coronal night. Should I try to capture my experience with photos? Or should I soak in the moment as deeply as I can?
2017-08-18.headline_main: Taking Photos Won’t Take You Out of the Moment, Study Suggests

2017-08-18.abstract: A new study analyzes how economists talk about each other in an online forum, and finds unmistakable signs of hostility toward women.
2017-08-18.snippet: A new study analyzes how economists talk about each other in an online forum, and finds unmistakable signs of hostility toward women.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: A pathbreaking new study of online conversations among economists describes and quantifies a workplace culture that appears to amount to outright hostility toward women in parts of the economics profession.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Evidence of a Toxic Environment for Women in Economics

2017-08-18.snippet: Patients often don’t recall what was said in the doctor’s office. Should you record the visit to review later?
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: The next time you see your cardiologist or internist, what would happen if you took out your smartphone or a digital recorder and said you’d like to record your appointment?
2017-08-18.headline_main: The Appointment Ends. Now the Patient Is Listening.

2017-08-18.abstract: The names of those who fought to keep slavery in place decorate streets, schools, bases — so widely that most people never think about it.
2017-08-18.snippet: The names of those who fought to keep slavery in place decorate streets, schools, bases — so widely that most people never think about it.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: As a son of the South, I’m glad to see folks finally getting their act together on the hundreds of Confederate monuments spread around the region — folks like the Republican governor of Tennessee, Bill Haslam, who recently endorsed removing a bust of Nathan Bedford Forrest from the state Capitol. That’s low-hanging fruit; Forrest was a Confederate monster who massacred black soldiers and later helped found the Klan. Still, it’s a start.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Confederate Statues Are the Easy Part

2017-08-18.abstract: A writer finds commercial success in Scott Spencer’s novel “River Under the Road,” but at what cost to his self-esteem and his marriage?
2017-08-18.snippet: A writer finds commercial success in Scott Spencer’s novel “River Under the Road,” but at what cost to his self-esteem and his marriage?
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: RIVER UNDER THE ROAD By Scott Spencer366 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

2017-08-18.abstract: Robert Wright, whose book “Why Buddhism Is True” is a best seller, has been a spiritual seeker for a long time.
2017-08-18.snippet: Robert Wright, whose book “Why Buddhism Is True” is a best seller, has been a spiritual seeker for a long time.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: OM’S LAW: To the extent that Buddhism encourages its practitioners to cast aside the self on their way to enlightenment, it can seem like a fool’s errand. The self isn’t so easy to shed, as Buckaroo Bonzai noted: “No matter where you go, there you are.” But that doesn’t mean there’s no wisdom to be found in the effort. The journalist Robert Wright — a practicing Buddhist who often explores the intersection of science and religion, as in his 2009 best seller “The Evolution of God” — makes the case for a Zen lifestyle in his latest book, “Why Buddhism Is True,” new at No. 4 in hardcover nonfiction.
2017-08-18.headline_main: A Science Writer Embraces Buddhism as a Path to Enlightenment

2017-08-18.abstract: Quitting a ceremonial council isn’t enough. They still need to work with the president to keep America on track.
2017-08-18.snippet: Quitting a ceremonial council isn’t enough. They still need to work with the president to keep America on track.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: New Haven — This week the American business community did something virtually unprecedented in its history: It shunned the call to national service by the commander in chief. In the wake of President Trump’s horrifying, un-American equivalence of neo-Nazi storm troopers with the peaceful counter-demonstrators at their weekend rally in Charlottesville, Va., first one, then another, then a flood of chief executives quit his business councils. Now they need to do more.
2017-08-18.headline_main: C.E.O.s Revolted Against Trump. Now Comes the Hard Part.

2017-08-18.abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: the legacy of Roland Barthes.

2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: On Page 17 of this week’s issue, Nicholas Dames reviews a novel that takes as its inspiration the accidental death of the French literary theorist Roland Barthes. Thirty-five years ago, Edmund White wrote in the Book Review about Barthes’s literary legacy.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Notes From the Book Review Archives

2017-08-18.abstract: The hip-hop choreographer Will Adams — WilldaBeast — is a standout among those who have honed their careers through social media.
2017-08-18.snippet: The hip-hop choreographer Will Adams — WilldaBeast — is a standout among those who have honed their careers through social media.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: POMONA, Calif. — On a Tuesday morning last month, hundreds of dancers gathered outside the Fairplex Conference Center here, waiting for the doors to open. Though they would spend the next five days dancing, some were getting a head start, freestyling on the sidewalk as people crowded around to watch. As one tossed off pirouettes, another edged into the circle, etching zigzags into the pavement with the soles of her yellow sneakers. There was no time to waste in being seen.
2017-08-18.headline_main: WilldaBeast, and Other Forces to Be Reckoned With

Watson, Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins were awarded the Nobel Prize in 1962 for their research on the subject.) 2017-08-18.abstract: On a former horse farm in New Jersey, Frank Gehry built Cai Guo-Qiang’s dream home.
2017-08-18.snippet: On a former horse farm in New Jersey, Frank Gehry built Cai Guo-Qiang’s dream home.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: The hourlong train ride from New York City to Morris County, N.J., cuts through the dreary industrial swamp of the Meadowlands, goes past the concrete caverns of Newark and edges along leafy college towns, before finally ending in Morristown, the county seat, a Revolutionary War stronghold and the former site of the curiously named Fort Nonsense, now a nondescript village full of hulking suburban houses. (In an episode of the final season of ‘‘The Sopranos,’’ Morristown is where Tony Soprano dreams he goes to die, just before waking from a gunshot-induced coma.) A 30-minute drive from Morristown is Chester, a tiny, bucolic community of horse farms, where families of deer amble down narrow roads and rolling hills loom hazily in the distant skyline. There, at the end of a dirt path, is a sight so unexpected that it feels as if it had descended from another world, quietly and without explanation: the country home of the artist Cai Guo-Qiang, designed by his friend Frank Gehry.
2017-08-18.headline_main: An Architect and an Artist Walk Into a Barn

2017-08-18.abstract: Of all the ways in which art and design test our understanding of the world, one of the most important is how they make us question what exactly beauty is.
2017-08-18.snippet: Of all the ways in which art and design test our understanding of the world, one of the most important is how they make us question what exactly beauty is.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: In the natural world, spring is the season of renewal. But in fashion — an unnatural world, though one equally transformative, and one that also runs on its own cycle of birth and death, birth and death — fall is the most fecund time of year. And not just in the fashion world, but in virtually every other creative world as well: art, theater, film, books. For these few months, we are either the watchers or the watched, and by the time the season’s finished, we are drunk with looking, with being challenged to see anew. A successful season in the culture is one that leaves you feeling one part giddy and one part uncomfortable — Is this what a dress looks like now? Is this what a novel should say and do? Is this art, or is it not?
2017-08-18.headline_main: T’s Women’s Fashion Issue: Editor’s Letter

2017-08-18.abstract: In some New York neighborhoods, the older a building is, the less rent you are likely to pay.

2017-08-18.abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.

2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Sand and waves provide the backdrop for this free summer series, which returns at 6 p.m. on Saturday with a pair of new works. “At Night” is a duet created in darkness by Jodi Melnick and Jon Kinzel, two mesmerizing movers allowing their solo dance practices to intersect. Also on the program is “Fun Young God,” created by an anonymous choreographer, in which Pierre Guilbault and Cori Kresge replicate the movements of rock and pop stars including Mick Jagger and Beyoncé, meshing those demeanors with their own to comment on celebrity, youth and faith. SIOBHAN BURKE

2017-08-18.abstract: Yuvraj Singh Dhesi, better known as Jinder Mahal, is helping the WWE attract fans from its next big target: India.
2017-08-18.snippet: Yuvraj Singh Dhesi, better known as Jinder Mahal, is helping the WWE attract fans from its next big target: India.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — “You people have nothing to celebrate,” Jinder Mahal shouted into a microphone on Tuesday night at the Dunkin’ Donuts Center. The current World Wrestling Entertainment champion was dressed in a black turban and a gray suit with his giant belt slung over his shoulder. He twisted his face into a deep, angry grimace, and continued, “But for my people, today marks Independence Day of the greatest nation on earth: the great nation of India!”
2017-08-18.headline_main: How Jinder Mahal, an Indian WWE Star, Is Turning Up the Heat

On Fifth Avenue and East 103rd Street, across from the New York Academy of Medicine, is an imposing monument to Dr. J. Marion Sims, whose fame as the father of modern gynecology came at the expense of enslaved black women on whom he operated without anesthesia or informed consent.

2017-08-18.abstract: At work we have no choice but to upgrade to the latest technology. At home, we can say no.
2017-08-18.snippet: At work we have no choice but to upgrade to the latest technology. At home, we can say no.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Recently, I gave up my electric toothbrush. There was nothing wrong with it. It was, in fact, an upscale model, and when I used it, I felt certain my teeth were not only getting cleaner and whiter but also perhaps even better aligned. And yet, my old manual toothbrush, poking out of a mug on the vanity, beckoned. One night, as I wearily approached the sink, I realized the last thing I wanted to experience was the frantic whir of yet another spinning gizmo. I plucked out the old-timey toothbrush instead, and never looked back.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Save Your Sanity. Downgrade Your Life.

2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: Slur the words just right, and it becomes hard to tell the difference between terrorism and tourism. Just months after Sept. 11, 2001, when nearly 3,000 people died in attacks on the World Trade Center, one of the first reactions of New Yorkers and visitors to the city was to flock to the site. The event defied comprehension; proximity, perhaps, offered a path to understanding.

2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, instead of showing up at her immigration check-in with a nonstop ticket to Guatemala, as she had been told to do, Amanda Morales Guerra, 33, walked into Holyrood Episcopal Church-Iglesia Santa Cruz in Washington Heights. She did not know when she could emerge again.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Told to Go Back to Guatemala, She Sought Sanctuary Instead

2017-08-18.abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

2017-08-18.abstract: A new ruling in a bitter legal battle over the future of driverless car technology could hurt Uber when the case goes to trial.
2017-08-18.snippet: A new ruling in a bitter legal battle over the future of driverless car technology could hurt Uber when the case goes to trial.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: In a strongly worded ruling on Thursday, a federal judge presiding over an intellectual property fight between Uber and Waymo, the self-driving car unit spun out of Google, said jurors in a coming trial may be told that Uber has been withholding key evidence.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Judge Says Waymo Can Tell Jurors That Uber Withheld Evidence

2017-08-18.abstract: New York pays more than 800 teachers without permanent jobs. Now it plans to put them into school vacancies, whether principals want them or not.
2017-08-18.snippet: New York pays more than 800 teachers without permanent jobs. Now it plans to put them into school vacancies, whether principals want them or not.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: For a dozen years, hundreds of New York City teachers have been paid despite not having permanent jobs, sidelined in most cases because of disciplinary problems or bad teaching records or because they had worked in poorly performing schools that were closed or where enrollment declined.
2017-08-18.headline_main: City Will Move Sidelined Teachers From Limbo to Classrooms

2017-08-18.abstract: “Darkness is good,” Bannon said. But to save his presidency, Trump needs to embrace the light.
2017-08-18.snippet: “Darkness is good,” Bannon said. But to save his presidency, Trump needs to embrace the light.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: The White House chief strategist Stephen K. Bannon’s departure was widely applauded, and not only by the Washington establishment Mr. Bannon has spent a career excoriating. After the news broke, traders at the New York Stock Exchange “literally cheered,” according to a CNBC report.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Steve Bannon Is Overrated

2017-08-18.abstract: Under John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, who once oversaw the prison in Cuba, the Trump administration is debating a potential executive order on detainees.
2017-08-18.snippet: Under John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, who once oversaw the prison in Cuba, the Trump administration is debating a potential executive order on detainees.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is making a fresh attempt at drafting an executive order on handling terrorism detainees, reviving a struggle to navigate legal and geopolitical obstacles to expand use of the Guantánamo Bay wartime prison, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.
2017-08-18.headline_main: Trump Officials Renew Effort to Expand Use of Prison at Guantánamo

2017-08-18.abstract: J.D. Droddy has been an Air Force officer, a lawyer, an educator, a playwright, a theatrical producer, a composer and a baseball boss. At 73, he’s looking for something new.
2017-08-18.snippet: J.D. Droddy has been an Air Force officer, a lawyer, an educator, a playwright, a theatrical producer, a composer and a baseball boss. At 73, he’s looking for something new.

2017-08-18.abstract: The agency’s political appointees pushed career staff members to draft an order rejecting a ban on a popular pesticide.
2017-08-18.snippet: The agency’s political appointees pushed career staff members to draft an order rejecting a ban on a popular pesticide.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the weeks before the Environmental Protection Agency decided to reject its own scientists’ advice to ban a potentially harmful pesticide, Scott Pruitt, the agency’s head, promised farming industry executives who wanted to keep using the pesticide that it is “a new day, and a new future,” and that he was listening to their pleas.
2017-08-18.headline_main: E.P.A. Promised ‘a New Day’ for the Agriculture Industry, Documents Reveal

2017-08-18.abstract: Convoluted infighting among warlords on the Afghan government side is creating deep resentments that are fueling the Taliban insurgency.
2017-08-18.snippet: Convoluted infighting among warlords on the Afghan government side is creating deep resentments that are fueling the Taliban insurgency.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The senior security official in northeastern Takhar Province was deferential when he telephoned Commander Bashir Qanet. After all, he was talking to one of the most powerful government supporters in the province, who has hundreds of militiamen under his command.
2017-08-18.headline_main: In Afghanistan, a Destructive ‘Game of Thrones’

2017-08-18.abstract: A longtime mantra used by many defenders is being undercut by the embrace of Confederate imagery by white supremacists.
2017-08-18.snippet: A longtime mantra used by many defenders is being undercut by the embrace of Confederate imagery by white supremacists.
2017-08-18.lead_paragraph: EUFAULA, Ala. — The facts of Southern history, according to Brad Griffin, are beyond dispute.
2017-08-18.headline_main: In Monument Debate, Calls for an Overdue Reckoning on Race and Southern Identity

2017-08-19.abstract: An email Thursday night from Mr. Murdoch was a repudiation of President Trump. It may signal a shift at Murdoch-controlled media outlets.
2017-08-19.snippet: An email Thursday night from Mr. Murdoch was a repudiation of President Trump. It may signal a shift at Murdoch-controlled media outlets.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: At 5:55 p.m. on Thursday, James Murdoch sent an email to a list of blind-copied recipients offering a striking repudiation of President Trump and a pledge to donate $1 million to the Anti-Defamation League. He addressed the note to “friends,” stating in the first line that he was writing it in a “personal capacity, as a concerned citizen and a father.”
2017-08-19.headline_main: James Murdoch’s Rebuke of Trump May Signal a Shift

2017-08-19.abstract: As the Virginia city becomes the latest flash point in the America’s fight over white supremacy, a deep-rooted struggle for equality has weighed heavily on a shrinking black population.
2017-08-19.snippet: As the Virginia city becomes the latest flash point in the America’s fight over white supremacy, a deep-rooted struggle for equality has weighed heavily on a shrinking black population.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — One of the joys of growing up, for Deborah Bell-Burks, was sitting on the counter of the general store that her family owned on Main Street, helping her mother bag items and count change. A bicycle ride through the neighborhood would take her past a grocery, a barbershop and a cobbler’s shop. And most of the people she would see, well-off business owners and customers alike, were black like her, offering an early lesson in what she could become.
2017-08-19.headline_main: In Charlottesville, Some Say Statue Debate Obscures a Deep Racial Split

2017-08-19.abstract: That jam at the end …
2017-08-19.snippet: That jam at the end …
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: Still shocked to discover how much I get out of this band, which I discovered so far into their career. (20-something relative: “*You* like *Warpaint*?”) Something deep about them — and this performance is one of the ones that get me most.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Friday Night Music: Warpaint, Elephants

2017-08-19.abstract: Yawkey owned the team for 44 seasons but fought suiting up a black player to the last. Now there is an effort to rename a street near Fenway Park that memorializes him.
2017-08-19.snippet: Yawkey owned the team for 44 seasons but fought suiting up a black player to the last. Now there is an effort to rename a street near Fenway Park that memorializes him.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — White vertical lines frame the first column of out-of-town scores on the famous left-field wall at Fenway Park. For decades, a series of dots and dashes have been embedded within those lines, a cryptic memorial hiding in plain sight.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Thomas Yawkey, the Red Sox Owner Who Resisted Integration

2017-08-19.abstract: At least we’ll never have to bronze Donald Trump.
2017-08-19.snippet: At least we’ll never have to bronze Donald Trump.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: I believe I have an answer to our statue problem.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Discovering the Limitations of Statues

2017-08-19.abstract: He is a Jabberwock president, nonsensical, menacing and beyond reason.
2017-08-19.snippet: He is a Jabberwock president, nonsensical, menacing and beyond reason.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: In the department of small violins, consider the moral embarrassment, after Charlottesville, Va., of right-of-center Jews who voted for Donald Trump in the election and remained — at least until last week — broadly supportive of his presidency.
2017-08-19.headline_main: President Jabberwock and the Jewish Right

2017-08-19.abstract: Mark Diehl fools us.
2017-08-19.snippet: Mark Diehl fools us.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s Saturday, and you hopefully now know what that means: There will be few gimmes, and even the fill-in-the-blanks clues will not be obvious. There’s a lot of wide open white space here and that can be intimidating, but that doesn’t mean you should back away from a good challenge.
2017-08-19.headline_main: It Covers Bridges

2017-08-19.abstract: New research reveals what American soldiers really thought of their South Vietnamese counterparts.
2017-08-19.snippet: New research reveals what American soldiers really thought of their South Vietnamese counterparts.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: Perhaps no one came out of the Vietnam War with a reputation as tarnished as the Army of the Republic of Vietnam. Since well before the war ended, ARVN soldiers were made an easy and ready scapegoat for America’s losses, a stereotype that found its way into academia and popular culture. We’re told they were incompetent cowards who often shirked their duties, leaving the hard work to the Americans.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Whose War Was It?

2017-08-19.abstract: In addition to Hayes, the team signed Pittsburgh’s Jamel Artis and Florida State’s Xavier Rathan-Mayes.
2017-08-19.snippet: In addition to Hayes, the team signed Pittsburgh’s Jamel Artis and Florida State’s Xavier Rathan-Mayes.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: The Knicks signed three free agents Friday, including Nigel Hayes, a forward from Wisconsin who helped lead the Badgers to two Final Fours and who became recognized later in his college career for his outspokenness in addressing social issues.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Nigel Hayes, an Outspoken Star With Wisconsin, Signs With the Knicks

2017-08-19.abstract: We can come back stronger, if we make the right choices, writes the city’s mayor.
2017-08-19.snippet: We can come back stronger, if we make the right choices, writes the city’s mayor.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: Charlottesville, Va. — Last weekend several thousand alt-right activists and white supremacists came to my city, ostensibly to protest our plan to move a statue of Robert E. Lee from Emancipation Park. We knew they were coming, but like the rest of the world, we were shocked by the level of bigotry and violence on display, culminating in the terrorist attack that killed one counterprotester, Heather Heyer.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Charlottesville Will Move On

2017-08-19.abstract: In brandishing weapons, militias added an edge of intimidation to protests that were ostensibly called as an exercise of constitutional rights.
2017-08-19.snippet: In brandishing weapons, militias added an edge of intimidation to protests that were ostensibly called as an exercise of constitutional rights.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: Even before violence erupted in Charlottesville, Va., last weekend, city residents and the police anxiously watched the arrival of self-styled militias — swaggering gangs of armed civilians in combat fatigues — standing guard over the protest by white supremacists and other racist agitators against the removal of a Confederate statue.
2017-08-19.headline_main: The Gunmen at ‘Free Speech’ Rallies

2017-08-19.abstract: Thousands of demonstrators poured into the nation’s streets and parks on Saturday to denounce white supremacy and Nazism.
2017-08-19.snippet: Thousands of demonstrators poured into the nation’s streets and parks on Saturday to denounce white supremacy and Nazism.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Tens of thousands of demonstrators, emboldened and unnerved by the eruption of fatal violence in Virginia last weekend, surged into the nation’s streets and parks on Saturday to denounce racism, white supremacy and Nazism.

2017-08-19.abstract: We know there will be more attacks. But how do societies that celebrate openness live with that?
2017-08-19.snippet: We know there will be more attacks. But how do societies that celebrate openness live with that?
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: There are always many questions after a terrorist attack, some never to be answered. Why a promenade in Barcelona and the seaside town of Cambrils? Why now? Were the terrorists compelled to act hastily after a more insidious plot collapsed when a house believed to be their bomb factory in a nearby town exploded prematurely on Wednesday?
2017-08-19.headline_main: After the Terror in Barcelona

2017-08-19.abstract: Lifting zoning restrictions in the garment district would destroy a historic area where craftsmanship still thrives.
2017-08-19.snippet: Lifting zoning restrictions in the garment district would destroy a historic area where craftsmanship still thrives.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: Manufacturing in New York City’s garment district is in jeopardy of unraveling at its seams. The city’s Economic Development Corporation may soon begin the certification process to lift the zoning laws that have protected fashion and apparel businesses in these few blocks in Midtown Manhattan for decades.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Save New York City’s Fashion Factories

2017-08-19.abstract: Richard Fausset, a Times reporter in Atlanta and a native of New Orleans, reflects on a lifetime and career dealing with symbolisms of the South.
2017-08-19.snippet: Richard Fausset, a Times reporter in Atlanta and a native of New Orleans, reflects on a lifetime and career dealing with symbolisms of the South.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: For years, I passed by the old Confederate battle flag sticker. It was affixed to a traffic sign on a lonesome four-lane rural road in Haralson County, Ga., the proud and hardscrabble patch of the rural South where my wife was raised.
2017-08-19.headline_main: In a Post-Charlottesville Nation, ‘Everything Feels Different and the Same’

2017-08-19.abstract: The design, which involves red, white and blue tiles, appears inside at least one subway station in Times Square. It’s one of many changes after Charlottesville.

2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: PEEPLI KHERA, India — On my last week in India, I went to say goodbye to Jahiruddin Mewati, the chief of a small village where I had made a dozen or so reporting trips.

2017-08-19.abstract: The Sugars, along with the writer Ashley C. Ford, answer letters from people questioning their relationships because of major changes in their partners’ bodies.
2017-08-19.snippet: The Sugars, along with the writer Ashley C. Ford, answer letters from people questioning their relationships because of major changes in their partners’ bodies.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: “I’ve been madly in love my boyfriend for over two years, but I’m thinking of backing out of the relationship because he’s gained weight and I’m no longer physically attracted to him. I’ve lost perspective. Please tell me what you think.” That’s a question the Sugars answer in this week’s episode from a writer who calls herself “Scared to Choose Wrong.”
2017-08-19.headline_main: ‘Dear Sugars’: How to Talk About Our Partners’ Bodies

2017-08-19.abstract: A photographer spent a couple of Sundays roaming the streets in Brooklyn and Harlem searching for finely dressed churchgoers.
2017-08-19.snippet: A photographer spent a couple of Sundays roaming the streets in Brooklyn and Harlem searching for finely dressed churchgoers.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: Andre Wagner’s father was a minister in Omaha, so church on Sunday was an all-day affair.  The day would start when his grandfather picked up the family in what he called his “Sunday van.” Andre sang in the choir, went to Sunday school and usually ended up having a meal at the home of another preacher. “You were spending time with people from church and being part of the community,” he said.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Sunday Best in Harlem and Brooklyn

2017-08-19.abstract: In an age of alternative facts, “fan fiction” about celebrities (living and dead) has become more popular.
2017-08-19.snippet: In an age of alternative facts, “fan fiction” about celebrities (living and dead) has become more popular.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: In a new novel called “Imagining Diana,” readers find Princess Diana having lunch in Midtown Manhattan at Michael’s, nodding hello to Barbara Walters on her way in, dressed in an Oscar de la Renta suit, sitting at Table 1, ordering the gravlax.
2017-08-19.headline_main: 20 Years After Diana’s Death, a Happier Ending Imagined

2017-08-19.abstract: Open since 1878, this seaside manse has become party central for a large group of Snapchatting, shot-chugging 20-somethings. It also serves lunch.
2017-08-19.snippet: Open since 1878, this seaside manse has become party central for a large group of Snapchatting, shot-chugging 20-somethings. It also serves lunch.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: SEA GIRT, N.J. — “I have a time share with the dance floor — I own the front and center,” Chris Fedroff, 27, said to his friend in the basement level of the Parker House, a green and white Victorian manse here that is by day a sedate lunch spot, by night a throbbing epicenter of summer parties.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Who Needs the Hamptons When You Have the Parker House?

2017-08-19.abstract: Two Times reporters discuss the latest events of the technology world, focusing this week on Apple, Uber and how tech companies took action against neo-Nazis.

Kelly, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister to preside at the event, officiated at the Manufacturers’ Golf and Country Club in Fort Washington, Pa. 2017-08-19.abstract: One man’s leafy privacy screen is another’s dread invasive species.
2017-08-19.snippet: One man’s leafy privacy screen is another’s dread invasive species.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: Q. Soon after we moved into our home in Bayside, Queens, 13 years ago, we planted bamboo in our backyard. The plants have grown quite large. We like how they look and the shade and privacy they provide. Recently, a neighbor demanded that we remove the bamboo, claiming that, as an invasive species, it is illegal to grow. He said the roots are invading his yard. We told him he could cut or destroy any roots or plants on his property, but that we would not remove bamboo from our yard. He has threatened to sue us. Must we remove the bamboo to avoid a lawsuit?
2017-08-19.headline_main: Neighbor Complains Bamboo Is Taking Over

2017-08-19.abstract: Virginia’s gubernatorial campaign was already set to be the highest profile race of the fall. Then came the Charlottesville violence and President Trump’s response.
2017-08-19.snippet: Virginia’s gubernatorial campaign was already set to be the highest profile race of the fall. Then came the Charlottesville violence and President Trump’s response.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: FALLS CHURCH, Va. — The bloody white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., has thrust race and history to the forefront of this year’s campaign for governor in Virginia, a tradition-bound state whose identity has always been rooted in a past that is as proud for some residents as it is painful for others.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Charlottesville and Trump’s Response Reshape Virginia Gubernatorial Race

2017-08-19.abstract: We always assumed America would protect the Jews. Luckily, we can protect ourselves.
2017-08-19.snippet: We always assumed America would protect the Jews. Luckily, we can protect ourselves.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: In the almost 20 years since we moved our three young children from a bucolic street in West Los Angeles to a Jerusalem apartment in the rough-and-tumble Middle East, my wife and I consciously taught them that in going from the United States to Israel, we had not been fleeing anything. We had moved not from something but to something. The country in which they were born, we reminded them time and again, not only was the greatest democracy on the planet (after which Israel largely models itself) but also has been unique in Jewish history. Everywhere else, Jews had lived tenuously, doing their best to be accepted until their host community eventually tired of them. When that happened — as in England in 1290, Spain in 1492 and Germany in 1933 — horror ensued.
2017-08-19.headline_main: Watching Charlottesville From Jerusalem

2017-08-19.abstract: When we’re older, we know more. But that’s not always an advantage.
2017-08-19.snippet: When we’re older, we know more. But that’s not always an advantage.
2017-08-19.lead_paragraph: One day not long ago, Augie, a 4-year-old Gopnik grandchild, heard his grandfather wistfully say, “I wish I could be a kid again.” After a thoughtful pause, Augie came up with a suggestion: Grandpa should try not eating any vegetables. The logic was ingenious: Eating vegetables turns children into big strong adults, so not eating vegetables should reverse the process.
2017-08-19.headline_main: What Happens to Creativity as We Age?

Below are some of the highlights, edited for space.

2017-08-20.lead_paragraph: Though classes had yet to start, the John F. Kennedy High School football team took to the field to practice for the opener against Father Dueñas Memorial. With Tumon Bay as their backdrop, the players warmed up beneath the August sun. Neither the threat of nuclear war nor 80 percent humidity could halt the dedication of the J.F.K. Islanders, and the same could be said for most others on this tiny Pacific island: Life goes on.
2017-08-20.headline_main: Young Voices on a Targeted Island: ‘Very Lucky to Be From Guam’

2017-08-20.abstract: Abelardo Morell’s “Thoreau: 40 Journals in Chronological Order” will go on view on Tuesday.
2017-08-20.snippet: Abelardo Morell’s “Thoreau: 40 Journals in Chronological Order” will go on view on Tuesday.
2017-08-20.lead_paragraph: In 1979, before he gained recognition for his photography, Abelardo Morell worked the night shift as a security guard for the Morgan Library & Museum. Now, Mr. Morell has donated a new work of art to the museum to honor its security staff. “Thoreau: 40 Journals in Chronological Order” will be on display at the Morgan from Tuesday through Sept. 10. as part of “This Ever New Self: Thoreau and His Journal,” which traces Henry David Thoreau’s life through notebooks and other artifacts. (“He is a model of resistance in a rived, self-destructive, demagogic political moment,” Holland Cotter wrote in a notebook on the exhibit.)
2017-08-20.headline_main: Photographer Donates Thoreau-Inspired Artwork to the Morgan

Dozens of people skim across the waters at speeds of up to 40 miles per hour, kites far ahead and their boards floating two feet above the chop of the waves. They move so smoothly and quietly that some riders are on their cellphones.

They called it the Blue Hole because of the crystalline quality of its water, and for many, a trip there was a cherished tradition.

2017-08-20.lead_paragraph: In her new memoir, “Rabbit,” Patricia Williams writes that there is no “simple answer” to the question of how she went “from living in an illegal liquor house, to running from the cops, to living in the suburbs with a flock of ducks outside my window.” This standup comedian, who performs as Ms. Pat, grew up in Atlanta during the crack epidemic, one of five children of an alcoholic single mother. By 15, Ms. Williams had two children of her own. She went on to sell crack (she was shot twice) and spent time in jail.
2017-08-20.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Patricia Williams Goes From Crime to Comedy

2017-08-20.abstract: The art historian in a critic wants to preserve Confederate images in museums, not trash them. At a crime scene, you don’t destroy evidence.

2017-08-20.lead_paragraph: It’s a summer of sequels. The culture wars are back. So is the civil rights movement. So is the Civil War. They were all in evidence in Charlottesville, Va., on Aug. 12, when a protest over the planned removal from a city park of a statue of the Southern Civil War general Robert E. Lee exploded in violence. Two sets of protesters met and clashed: a battalion of white nationalists, neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klanners and a crowd of counterprotesters, some with Black Lives Matter placards.
2017-08-20.headline_main: We Need to Move, Not Destroy, Confederate Monuments

2017-08-20.abstract: Tom McCoy gives us good advice.
2017-08-20.snippet: Tom McCoy gives us good advice.
2017-08-20.lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — London is a huge city, and without a doubt, the most convenient way to get around is the London Underground, or Tube. As a native New Yorker, it was a revelation to me that I could ride on a subway system that 1) was either air-conditioned or extremely well-ventilated, 2) offered free Wi-Fi, 3) was inhabited by citizens who seemingly had no interest in bothering one another for any reason other than to ask directions in the politest, most British way possible, and 4) was mostly unscented, in the sense that no one had recently urinated in public. It is also fast and relatively quiet.
2017-08-20.headline_main: Something to Mind

2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: Did you know that there are only three episodes of “Twin Peaks: The Return” left: one airing next week, and two the Sunday before Labor Day? Lately I’ve seen some chatter on social media lamenting how close we are to the end, mainly because it’s becoming increasingly apparent that David Lynch and Mark Frost have no plans to bring back the chipper, can-do form of Agent Dale Cooper until close to the end of the series (if even then). Some fans are miffed that one of the elements that defined the original “Twin Peaks” may never become a significant part of this revival.

2017-08-21.abstract: Pay less attention to taxing and spending, more to power.
2017-08-21.snippet: Pay less attention to taxing and spending, more to power.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: With Steve Bannon out of the White House, it’s clearer than ever that Donald Trump’s promise to be a populist fighting for ordinary workers was worth about as much as any other Trump promise — that is, nothing. His agenda, such as it is, amounts to reverse Robin Hood with extra racism — the conventional Republican strategy of taking from struggling families to give to the rich, while distracting lower-income whites by attacking Those People, with the only difference being just how blatantly he plays the race card.
2017-08-21.headline_main: What Will Trump Do to American Workers?

2017-08-21.abstract: The food service industry is a growing part of our economy, and it has a big substance abuse problem.
2017-08-21.snippet: The food service industry is a growing part of our economy, and it has a big substance abuse problem.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: My former co-worker once drank so much during a waitressing shift, she stumbled through the restaurant with her intoxication on full display to guests. Even the chaos of the service rush couldn’t hide the state she was in. By closing she was fired.
2017-08-21.headline_main: Why Waiters Drink. And Why It Matters.

2017-08-21.abstract: A “heritage” of racism still taints the sport’s fandom.
2017-08-21.snippet: A “heritage” of racism still taints the sport’s fandom.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: It may be a sweltering August day in the Deep South, but football fans across the region are readying their R.V.s and face paint, making plans for the tailgate feast and nervously reading injury reports on their team’s star players as they prepare for the opening of the college football season. I grew up in south Louisiana, where the weeks leading up to Louisiana State University’s home opener always felt like an extended night before Christmas: a combination of giddy excitement, nostalgia and anxious anticipation of a day that seemed it would never come. Football was life; the rest of the year was just biding time.
2017-08-21.headline_main: College Football Is Here. But What Are We Really Cheering?

2017-08-21.abstract: For a while, African-American writers and artists thought that Soviet communism might allow them to make work beyond the color line.
2017-08-21.snippet: For a while, African-American writers and artists thought that Soviet communism might allow them to make work beyond the color line.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: In June 1932, the poet Langston Hughes arrived in Moscow as a part of group of 22 African-Americans who had been hired to act in a Soviet film about race relations and labor disputes in the American South. The cast had been assembled by Louise Thompson, an African-American activist who helped found the Harlem branch of the Friends of the Soviet Union, an initiative of the Communist International. Thompson saw in the film (which had the remarkably literal title “Black and White”) an opportunity to counter the distorted and stereotypical depictions of the African-American experience that plagued Hollywood films.
2017-08-21.headline_main: When the Harlem Renaissance Went to Communist Moscow

They document a rally, “Unite the Right,” where a protest over the removal of a Confederate monument served as a smokescreen for spewing racist and anti-Semitic hate. They show the counterprotesters who gathered to uphold the values of democracy and justice. They depict the murder and injury of some of these courageous individuals.

2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: White supremacist marchers had not yet lit their torches when the deletions began. The ‘‘Unite the Right’’ Facebook page, which had been used to organize the rally in Charlottesville, was removed the day before the event was scheduled, forcing planners to disperse to other platforms to organize. And then, in the hours and days after a participant drove his car into a crowd of counterprotesters, killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer and injuring at least 19 others, internet companies undertook a collective purge.

A new wave of campers is taking to the great outdoors, though you might not find them in A-frame tents. They’re in tree houses and Airstreams, king beds and plush robes, prompting campgrounds to install Wi-Fi, and inspiring start-ups to build hotel-caliber apps and websites for discovering and booking campsites with zip lines and fine food.

That last issue has undergone one of the greatest transformations in polling over the last 50 years. In 1960, just 4 percent of Americans approved.

Now, the restaurant serves beers made on-site, which can include a mellow farmhouse ale, a fruity hefeweizen, a gently citric Belgian-style ale, a golden I.P.A. suggesting black tea, a honeyed amber I.P.A. and an aggressively tart Berliner weisse. 2017-08-21.snippet: Sold by the dozen, this tempered glassware from Food 52 beats plastic party cups.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: These simple drinking glasses come from Spain, where they’re used everywhere. Multipurpose and made of tempered glass, they can be neatly stacked and suit a tight budget. Use the small (7.5 ounces) for wine, a panna cotta, yogurt and berries, or serving condiments and pickles. The midsize (12 ounces) is perfect for cocktails like a Negroni or an old-fashioned, as well as milk or iced tea. And the largest (17 ounces) is ample for your pint of brew: Stackable Bodega Glasses, $25 to $35 a dozen, food52.com.

2017-08-21.abstract: Rotisserie Georgette shares the recipe for its savory mini-madeleines.
2017-08-21.snippet: Rotisserie Georgette shares the recipe for its savory mini-madeleines.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: This summer Rôtisserie Georgette started serving savory mini-madeleines with drinks. The recipe is easily made at home. Heat oven to 375 degrees. Butter a mini-madeleine pan. Whisk together 1 cup cake flour, ½ teaspoon white pepper, ¼ teaspoon cream of tartar, 1 teaspoon baking powder and 1 tablespoon herbes de Provence. In a separate bowl, beat 4 eggs with 2 tablespoons sugar until thick and light, about 4 minutes. Add dry ingredients to eggs and mix in 3 ounces butter, melted. Add 1 cup finely grated Parmesan cheese and ¼ cup minced niçoise olives. Fill mini-madeleine pan and bake about 8 minutes, until lightly browned. Remove madeleines from pan and repeat to use all the batter. The recipe makes about 75, and they freeze well. Pair them with rosé: Rôtisserie Georgette, 14 East 60th Street, 212-390-8060, rotisserieg.com.
2017-08-21.headline_main: For That Glass of Rosé, Remember the Savory Snacks

2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: The 92nd Street Y kicks off its culinary talks this fall with Michael W. Twitty, left, a writer who covers African-American food history on his blog, Afroculinaria. He will discuss his new book, “The Cooking Gene: A Journey Through African American Culinary History in the Old South,” which explores his family and how generations of cooking traditions affect communities: “The Cooking Gene,” $29, 7 p.m., Sept. 7, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (East 92nd Street), 212-415-5500, 92y.org.

2017-08-21.abstract: I.M. Pastry Studio has opened an outpost in the Essex Street Market, and its treats are named for famous women.
2017-08-21.snippet: I.M. Pastry Studio has opened an outpost in the Essex Street Market, and its treats are named for famous women.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: Inspired by her grandmother’s baking, Tiffany Washington, above, began turning out cupcakes and cookies for friends in 2009. Last year, she and a business partner, Tamika Young, opened a small shop in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, but closed it when Manhattan beckoned. From a studio apartment-size kitchen and display counter in the Essex Street Market, Ms. Washington bakes and sells tender cupcakes with swirled frosting topknots, which start at $2.50, and red velvet and lemon Bundt cakes as well as brownies and cookies, all named for women like Oprah Winfrey and Beyoncé. The shop’s name is a reference to Ms. Washington’s grandmother, Ilene Miriam: I.M. Pastry Studio, Essex Street Market, 120 Essex Street (Delancey Street), 212-254-2112, impastrystudio.com.
2017-08-21.headline_main: Cupcakes That Pay Tribute to Grandma, and Beyoncé

2017-08-21.abstract: Lewis wanted to believe he was an ordinary American. But his creative success was borne of the tension that his very real difference created.
2017-08-21.snippet: Lewis wanted to believe he was an ordinary American. But his creative success was borne of the tension that his very real difference created.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: Jerry Lewis, who died Sunday at 91, was not a man often overlooked, or pigeonholed. But in reckoning with his legacy, there is often one surprising omission. He’s rarely featured in discussions of the pantheon of mid-20th century Jewish comedy. Possibly this was because of his overwhelming popularity, tending to remove the necessity for any qualifying adjective. Looking at pictures of the crowds flocking to catch a glimpse of him and his partner, Dean Martin, at their hotels, you’d think you were witnessing Beatlemania. Only Martin and Lewis were 10 years earlier.
2017-08-21.headline_main: Jerry Lewis Was the Quintessential American Jew

2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: Nashville — I grew up on Missionary Ridge, a Civil War battlefield overlooking Chattanooga, Tenn. In my childhood we could still find minie balls from the battle in which a young Union soldier, Arthur MacArthur, the father of Douglas, received the Medal of Honor. The war’s relics were real and tangible — I still have a few on my desk as I write — and so were the war’s perennial and tragic consequences.
2017-08-21.headline_main: Why Lee Should Go, and Washington Should Stay

2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: Although he grew up in Wisconsin farm country, the chef Joshua McFadden says he never saw a fresh beet, in the ground or in the kitchen, until he began cooking professionally. “Canned and pickled is all I knew,” he said. “And I didn’t like them either way.” Now, at his restaurants Ava Gene’s and Tusk in Portland, Ore., he is the kind of chef who cooks beets in all ways and in all seasons, from the tip of the root to the tall green-and-magenta tops.

2017-08-21.abstract: As the world’s forests are carved up by roads and farms, the animals in them are vanishing. A simple fix may help.
2017-08-21.snippet: As the world’s forests are carved up by roads and farms, the animals in them are vanishing. A simple fix may help.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, an ecologist named Thomas Lovejoy conducted an unusual experiment in Brazil’s Amazon rain forest. As loggers moved in with chain saws to clear trees for cattle pasture north of Manaus, he asked them to leave untouched several small “islands” of forest to see how the animals within them fared.
2017-08-21.headline_main: Stitching Together Forests Can Help Save Species, Study Finds

2017-08-21.abstract: Dale Chihuly, an artistic trailblazer who has long worked with teams, is facing a court battle that opens a complicated debate about age, infirmity and ego.
2017-08-21.snippet: Dale Chihuly, an artistic trailblazer who has long worked with teams, is facing a court battle that opens a complicated debate about age, infirmity and ego.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — More than 40 years later, Jeffrey Beers still vividly remembers what it felt like to have Dale Chihuly call up to convene a pre-dawn glassblowing session. You felt flattered and inspired, he said, jazzed by Mr. Chihuly’s caffeinated freight train of energy and the idea of making art with him while most of the world slept in.
2017-08-21.headline_main: Who Is Really Making ‘Chihuly Art’?

Putin on Monday named a career diplomat and arms control expert who is under European Union sanctions as the next Russian ambassador to Washington, replacing an envoy drawn into the swirling questions surrounding contacts between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin.

2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: When Heidi Imhof started losing her hair at 42, she also started losing sleep. Ms. Imhof, a lawyer, was afraid that blow-drying her straight dark hair would hasten the shedding, so she got up two hours early to shower and apply mousse and volumizers. When her hair finally air-dried, she’d pull it back, hoping to hide the bald patches on her scalp.

2017-08-21.abstract: “Not everybody loves them as much as I do,” Mr. Kushner says of the ceramic angels hanging in the house he shares with his husband, Mark Harris.
2017-08-21.snippet: “Not everybody loves them as much as I do,” Mr. Kushner says of the ceramic angels hanging in the house he shares with his husband, Mark Harris.
2017-08-21.lead_paragraph: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. — “I don’t have a big angel collection, but …” the “Angels in America” playwright Tony Kushner insisted with an embarrassed laugh. After all, evidence to the contrary — via a sculpture’s outstretched wings — nearly smacked a reporter in the head as he entered Mr. Kushner’s home here. Suspended from the ceiling, just past the doorway, was an infant-size ceramic angel created by the Peruvian-born Philadelphia artist Kukuli Velarde — one of four such angels hanging in the house Mr. Kushner shares with his husband, Mark Harris.
2017-08-21.headline_main: For Tony Kushner, It’s Angels Over the Breakfast Nook
