2017-08-26.abstract: Chinese investments in Greece are beginning to pay off, not only economically, but also by providing Beijing with a seemingly reliable ally in Brussels.
2017-08-26.snippet: Chinese investments in Greece are beginning to pay off, not only economically, but also by providing Beijing with a seemingly reliable ally in Brussels.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — After years of struggling under austerity imposed by European partners and a chilly shoulder from the United States, Greece has embraced the advances of China, its most ardent and geopolitically ambitious suitor.

2017-08-26.abstract: At a golf course managed by the president’s company, migrant workers employed by a local contractor complain they are not paid on time.
2017-08-26.snippet: At a golf course managed by the president’s company, migrant workers employed by a local contractor complain they are not paid on time.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — They are not inclined to complain, not about the merciless sun or the 110-degree heat, as they labor to transform the pale sands of the Arabian desert into verdant fairways. They accept with resignation that their families are far away, in India, Pakistan or Nepal.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Late Wages for Migrant Workers at a Trump Golf Course in Dubai

2017-08-26.abstract: The Sugars, along with the writer Julie Barton, answer letters about pet dilemmas and the ways these creatures affect human relationships.
2017-08-26.snippet: The Sugars, along with the writer Julie Barton, answer letters about pet dilemmas and the ways these creatures affect human relationships.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: When a rural couple turns their home into a mini-animal rescue — five special-needs dogs, a cat, four kittens, two goats and a pair of pigs — chaos ensues. They each have full-time jobs and now can’t keep up with all the demands at home. “How do we solve this problem? I know we may have overcommitted, but now we’re here. So what next?”

2017-08-26.abstract: The Negev Desert offers craters, cliffs, oases, Arabian leopards — and inexpensive lodging.

2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: The stark Negev Desert, filled with craters, multicolored sand and clusters of Bedouin villages, comprises more than half of Israel’s total mass. And thanks to a bevy of new promotions on desert lodging and tourism, savvy travelers looking to stretch their shekels in the Holy Land will find the Negev an affordable alternative to Jerusalem or Tel Aviv.

Friends and family were celebrating the return of a young singer and human rights activist who had just been released from jail.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death

2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: MANILA — Thousands of Filipinos poured out of their homes to join a funeral march on Saturday for Kian Loyd delos Santos, the 17-year-old boy whose death at the hands of the police has galvanized opposition to President Rodrigo Duterte’s brutal war on drugs.

2017-08-26.abstract: Forced to adapt or fizzle out, the country’s propaganda machine has embraced the latest trends and technologies to appeal to the sensibilities of young Iranians. Watch some of the most popular.
2017-08-26.snippet: Forced to adapt or fizzle out, the country’s propaganda machine has embraced the latest trends and technologies to appeal to the sensibilities of young Iranians. Watch some of the most popular.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — It’s a common theme in the state-controlled media in Iran: The armed forces are not to be trifled with; they’re tough men doing a tough job, defending a country permanently under threat. Nevertheless, it was a shock to some young Iranians when a video appeared featuring a well-known rapper delivering the same message from the deck of a navy frigate.
2017-08-26.headline_main: As ‘Death to America’ Chants Lose Power, Iran Retools Propaganda With Rap Videos

2017-08-26.abstract: A co-op resident asks for advice about a super’s unwanted advances and a do-nothing board.
2017-08-26.snippet: A co-op resident asks for advice about a super’s unwanted advances and a do-nothing board.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: Q. A month after I bought a co-op in Kensington, Brooklyn, I had an unnerving encounter with the super. I was retrieving a package and he grabbed me in a bearhug and growled. Days later, when he was in my apartment making repairs, he pulled me into another embrace, kissing me above my bosom. When I told the board president, she described him as “a good family man” and refused to intervene. I wrote the board and the managing agent a letter. They responded, saying that I should not speak with him “until investigations are complete.” That was a year ago. Now, I cannot ask the super for services, while other shareholders can. For example, the building has a plumbing issue. While the super has repaired other units, I was told to hire a licensed plumber at my own expense. What do I do?
2017-08-26.headline_main: What to Do if the Super Gropes You

2017-08-26.abstract: Mutual friends told them they’d be a perfect fit, but the timing never seemed quite right.

2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: Catherine Aloi Rivkin and Timothy Maxwell Visser were married Aug. 26 at the home of the bride’s parents in Cutchogue, N.Y. Judge Denise L. Cote of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, for whom the bride served as a law clerk, officiated. Judge Liam O'Grady of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, for whom the groom served as a law clerk, also took part.

2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to pardon Joe Arpaio was characteristically unconventional. It came late on a Friday night as a hurricane bore down on Texas. It concerned a crime some said was particularly ill-suited to clemency, and it was not the product of the care and deliberation that have informed pardons by other presidents.

2017-08-26.abstract: Once you can identify a few species, you find yourself beginning to pay attention.
2017-08-26.snippet: Once you can identify a few species, you find yourself beginning to pay attention.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: For several years, I’ve led tree walks in Washington, D.C. I start by asking participants who they are and why they want to spend precious hours looking at trees. My students are nearly all highly educated, successful people who work impressive jobs, speak multiple languages and effortlessly command sophisticated computers and phones. Yet most know barely the first thing about the trees around them. They want to change that.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Cure Yourself of Tree Blindness

2017-08-26.abstract: As the ice melts, a Russian tanker sets a record, and sets off worries about the fragile environment.
2017-08-26.snippet: As the ice melts, a Russian tanker sets a record, and sets off worries about the fragile environment.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: The passage of a specially built Russian tanker carrying liquefied natural gas through the warming Arctic without an icebreaker escort marks a critical milestone in a centuries-old yearning for a shorter, faster route between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
2017-08-26.headline_main: The Rush to Exploit the Arctic

2017-08-26.abstract: It feels better to be the victimizer than the victim.
2017-08-26.snippet: It feels better to be the victimizer than the victim.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: What I know of rural white America mostly begins and ends with the three times I went at the age of 8 to visit a friend’s farm in Butler County, Pa., about an hour north of Pittsburgh, where I grew up. I recall vast farmland, ample sunshine and no black people — or Hispanics or Jews, or for that matter, half-Iranian, half-Jewish people like me. There was, however, my friend’s father, who found it amusing to make fun of my name over dinner, coming up with a wide variety of ways to mispronounce it each time. I did my best to politely correct him each time, until it finally became apparent to me that I was participating in a game in which there was no chance of winning, and I ran from the table and out of the house and cried among the farmland.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Two Lessons in Prejudice

2017-08-26.abstract: One thing we know how to do in Seoul is wait.
2017-08-26.snippet: One thing we know how to do in Seoul is wait.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: Within 13 hours of North Korea’s second intercontinental ballistic missile test launch last month, I attended a music festival on the banks of the Han River. Seoul, South Korea, was in the middle of a heat wave, a still, swampy kind of heat oppressive enough that an extreme weather alert had gone out from all major cell carriers several days in a row. “Be sure to stay hydrated,” my phone chirped. “Stay indoors when possible.”
2017-08-26.headline_main: Brit-Pop for a Nuclear Standoff

2017-08-26.abstract: My ancestors were a resourceful bunch. Here, they’ve fashioned a coat rack out of a tree stump. Here, a cinder block serves as a nightstand.
2017-08-26.snippet: My ancestors were a resourceful bunch. Here, they’ve fashioned a coat rack out of a tree stump. Here, a cinder block serves as a nightstand.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone. Thanks to the archaeology department for all that you’ve taught me. Go, class of 2617! My excavation of an ancient condo — long thought to belong to my ancestors — revealed some unexpected findings that dispute the persisting idea that they were wealthy. I’ll get right to my slides.
2017-08-26.headline_main: The Hunter-Gatherers of 2017

2017-08-26.abstract: What’s the point of seeing the Kaaba if you can’t appreciate the miracle that is two maniac toddlers running around after midnight?
2017-08-26.snippet: What’s the point of seeing the Kaaba if you can’t appreciate the miracle that is two maniac toddlers running around after midnight?
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: It’s midnight, three days before I leave for my first hajj, the five-day religious pilgrimage that’s among the most meaningful experiences in a Muslim’s life. When I arrive in Mecca, I’ll join nearly two million believers who’ve traveled from Virginia, Kabul, and everywhere in between: a dysfunctional but tight-knit family of believers, dreamers and sinners, briefly united under the piercing sun of Mecca.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Preparing for Hajj With a Case of ‘Dad Brain’

2017-08-26.snippet: Let’s reach beyond our Twitter feeds and show we care about words again.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: LATE one night this spring, Justin Snider, an assistant dean at Columbia University, was riding the uptown No. 2 in Manhattan when the train ground to a halt. After about 15 minutes — with little information about the delay and no cell service — everyone in the car was getting restless. Suddenly, inspiration struck. “I asked neighboring passengers if they wanted to hear some Shakespeare, and no one objected,” Mr. Snider told me.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Memorize That Poem!

2017-08-26.abstract: The American Tennis Association held its centennial national championships this month in Baltimore, where players treasured the sense of community.

2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Other African-American sports organizations, such as baseball’s Negro Leagues, faded after integration, but the American Tennis Association has remained vibrant.
2017-08-26.headline_main: 100 Years of Fostering African-American Tennis Talent

2017-08-26.abstract: A 1977 column in The New York Times recounted the last time the United States Open was played at the West Side Tennis Club.
2017-08-26.snippet: A 1977 column in The New York Times recounted the last time the United States Open was played at the West Side Tennis Club.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note: The West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, hosted the United States Open from 1915 to 1920 and then annually from 1924 to 1977. By then, the club was thought to be too small for a Grand Slam event and a new tennis center was under construction in Flushing Meadows, a few miles away. Dave Anderson wrote the following column about the final day at Forest Hills, when Guillermo Vilas defeated Jimmy Connors for the men’s singles title. It was originally published on Sept. 12, 1977.
2017-08-26.headline_main: The U.S. Open’s Last Day at Forest Hills

2017-08-26.abstract: Murray, who won the event in 2012, said he had been trying to heal since the French Open.
2017-08-26.snippet: Murray, who won the event in 2012, said he had been trying to heal since the French Open.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: The United States Open, already stung by the absences of several marquee players, lost another on Saturday when Andy Murray, the three-time Grand Slam champion and the No. 2 men’s seed, withdrew because of a lingering hip injury.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Andy Murray Withdraws From the U.S. Open Because of a Hip Injury

2017-08-26.abstract: Walker, perhaps the PGA Tour’s only photographer of celestial events, missed the total solar eclipse on Monday to see a doctor about his Lyme disease.
2017-08-26.snippet: Walker, perhaps the PGA Tour’s only photographer of celestial events, missed the total solar eclipse on Monday to see a doctor about his Lyme disease.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: OLD WESTBURY, N.Y. — As the first total eclipse of the sun in 38 years traced its arc across the United States on Monday, Jimmy Walker sat in a doctor’s office in Wilton, Conn., hoping for good news about his yearlong bout with Lyme disease.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Jimmy Walker’s Hobby Takes a Back Seat to His Health

2017-08-26.abstract: The death toll of an Islamic State attack on a Shiite mosque in Kabul rose to at least 40, and some of the victims were buried in the mosque’s garden.
2017-08-26.snippet: The death toll of an Islamic State attack on a Shiite mosque in Kabul rose to at least 40, and some of the victims were buried in the mosque’s garden.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Overnight, a small garden of pink and red roses at a Shiite mosque in Kabul was turned into a cemetery.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Graves Fill an Afghan Mosque’s Garden After a Terrorist Attack

2017-08-26.abstract: “Everyone in here wants it for him,” third baseman Jake Lamb said of Goldschmidt, who leads the league in several offensive categories.
2017-08-26.snippet: “Everyone in here wants it for him,” third baseman Jake Lamb said of Goldschmidt, who leads the league in several offensive categories.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: The Arizona Diamondbacks were losing badly last Sunday in Minnesota, so their manager, Torey Lovullo, removed Paul Goldschmidt in the seventh inning. Goldschmidt protested, asking him to rest other players who needed it more. Lovullo sat him down anyway, because Goldschmidt may be the most valuable player in the National League and keeping him fresh is critical. Yet the Diamondbacks’ star player had proved a point.
2017-08-26.headline_main: Paul Goldschmidt’s Teammates Cheer His M.V.P. Campaign

2017-08-26.abstract: Despite anxiety over the Affordable Care Act’s stability, many insurance companies still participating have cut losses sharply. Some are starting to prosper.

2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: It has not been a market for the faint of heart.

2017-08-26.abstract: Hundreds of thousands marched in Barcelona for a peace rally after last week’s attack on Las Ramblas, the city’s most famous promenade.
2017-08-26.snippet: Hundreds of thousands marched in Barcelona for a peace rally after last week’s attack on Las Ramblas, the city’s most famous promenade.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Half a million people gathered in the heart of Barcelona on Saturday, clutching roses and holding banners denouncing violence and extremism, but also bearing signs warning against Islamophobia and calling on Spanish leaders to stop selling weapons.
2017-08-26.headline_main: ‘I’m Not Afraid’: Barcelona Holds Peace Rally After Deadly Attacks

2017-08-26.abstract: Singapore’s language scene was once “a linguistic tropical rain forest,” chaotic but vibrant. Then came a campaign to limit speech to just English and Mandarin. Now, dialects are coming back.
2017-08-26.snippet: Singapore’s language scene was once “a linguistic tropical rain forest,” chaotic but vibrant. Then came a campaign to limit speech to just English and Mandarin. Now, dialects are coming back.
2017-08-26.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The Tok and Teo families are a model of traditional harmony, with three generations gathered under one roof, enjoying each other’s company over slices of fruit and cups of tea on a Saturday afternoon in Singapore.
2017-08-26.headline_main: In Singapore, Chinese Dialects Revive After Decades of Restrictions

2017-08-27.abstract: James Atlas, who has written about the lives of Saul Bellow and Delmore Schwartz, talks about his new book, “The Shadow in the Garden.”
2017-08-27.snippet: James Atlas, who has written about the lives of Saul Bellow and Delmore Schwartz, talks about his new book, “The Shadow in the Garden.”
2017-08-27.lead_paragraph: In his new book, “The Shadow in the Garden: A Biographer’s Tale,” James Atlas writes about the time he spent in the early 1970s studying with the esteemed biographer Richard Ellmann, whose books about James Joyce and Oscar Wilde are widely considered two of the greatest examples of the form. “Ellmann’s ‘Joyce’ didn’t read like a biography: it read like a work of art,” Atlas writes. “It had the authority of great fiction; it was scholarly but not academic; and behind its facade of objectivity you could detect, if you listened closely enough, the biographer’s own voice. This was the kind of book I aspired to write.” Atlas went on to become a publisher, editor and the author of biographies of Saul Bellow and the poet Delmore Schwartz. His new book is about the art of biography: how Atlas came to love it; how it’s been practiced through the ages; the magic it can work and its shortcomings. Below he talks about his conversations with Bellow, his struggles starting out on this latest project and more.
2017-08-27.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: The Art of Writing Biographies

2017-08-27.lead_paragraph: In the week that followed Hurricane Harvey’s landfall, photographers on the ground in Texas and Louisiana documented the staggering aftermath, including crowded shelters full of evacuees, the tireless efforts of emergency workers, and the return of residents to assess the damage from an event described by the National Weather Service as “unprecedented.”
2017-08-27.headline_main: Harvey in Pictures

2017-08-27.abstract: Texas has seen plenty of storms and floods in my time, but never water like this.
2017-08-27.snippet: Texas has seen plenty of storms and floods in my time, but never water like this.
2017-08-27.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — “We are way overdue,” my friend Alison said a few weeks ago, and the hairs on the back of my neck stood up in agreement. If you have lived in Houston long enough, as I have, you know that big storms come with the territory. I can trace much of my history through weather crises — Carla (1961), Alicia (1983), Allison (2001), the Katrina/Rita combo (2005), Ike (2008), and now Harvey, which looks to be the worst yet.
2017-08-27.headline_main: And Then the Rain Came

2017-08-28.abstract: Heavy rainfall from Tropical Storm Harvey has paralyzed the nation’s fourth-largest city. Five are dead; officials fear more trouble with more rain.
2017-08-28.snippet: Heavy rainfall from Tropical Storm Harvey has paralyzed the nation’s fourth-largest city. Five are dead; officials fear more trouble with more rain.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — What felt like an apocalyptic onslaught of pounding rains and rapidly rising floodwaters brought the nation’s fourth-largest city to its knees on Sunday, as highways and residential streets turned to rivers, waist-high waters choked off access to homes and hospitals, and officials begged boat owners to pitch in with an enormous and frantic rescue operation.
2017-08-28.headline_main: In Houston, Anxiety and Frantic Rescues as Floodwaters Rise

He sat in the back seat of an S.U.V. making its way from the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens to Manhattan’s Upper West Side for a photo shoot. He had no time to eat, so he brought four trays of sushi.

2017-08-28.snippet: Johnson, the world No. 1, overcame a five-shot deficit to win the Northern Trust on the first extra hole after forcing the playoff with a long par putt.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: OLD WESTBURY, N.Y. — Dustin Johnson is known for his distance, and he did not disappoint the fans who flocked to Glen Oaks to see him smash balls like Aaron Judge taking batting practice. His final drive at the Northern Trust — on the 475-yard par-4 18th hole, where he and Jordan Spieth began a sudden-death playoff — measured 341 yards and took a water hazard along the left side out of play.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Dustin Johnson Goes the Distance After His Short Game Gives Him a Chance

2017-08-28.abstract: A long-awaited moment finally arrives.
2017-08-28.snippet: A long-awaited moment finally arrives.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Every week as I prepare to write about “Twin Peaks,” I pull up the show’s Wikipedia page, so I’ll have all the actors’ and characters’ names in front of me. That means each week I see the introduction to that page, which ends with a quote from Showtime’s president, David Nevins, describing the 18-hour maxi-series as “Agent Cooper’s odyssey back to Twin Peaks.” Maybe that’s why I haven’t been too concerned about how Kyle MacLachlan’s been stuck week after week playing the evil Mr. C and the addled Dougie Jones, instead of fast-talking, gung-ho lawman Dale Cooper.
2017-08-28.headline_main: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 3, Episode 16: Doppelgängers and Dancers

2017-08-28.abstract: How many Republicans will refuse to collaborate?
2017-08-28.snippet: How many Republicans will refuse to collaborate?
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: As sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., Joe Arpaio engaged in blatant racial discrimination. His officers systematically targeted Latinos, often arresting them on spurious charges and at least sometimes beating them up when they questioned those charges. Read the report from the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division, and prepare to be horrified.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Fascism, American Style

2017-08-28.abstract: It’s not the same as the far right. That doesn’t mean we shouldn’t expect more violence.
2017-08-28.snippet: It’s not the same as the far right. That doesn’t mean we shouldn’t expect more violence.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: During his speech in Phoenix on Tuesday night, Donald Trump spat out the nickname “antifa,” short for “anti-fascist” but also a reference to a particular strand of aggressive left-wing activism. In Mr. Trump’s telling, the presence of antifa activists during the violence in Charlottesville, Va., this month was evidence that the far left is just as violent as the far right: “You know, they show up in the helmets and the black masks, and they’ve got clubs and they’ve got everything.”
2017-08-28.headline_main: Who’s Afraid of Antifa?

2017-08-28.abstract: Washington is in denial, but California and nine Northeastern states are forging ahead.
2017-08-28.snippet: Washington is in denial, but California and nine Northeastern states are forging ahead.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: The one bright spot amid the generally gloomy news about climate change, and the Trump administration’s resistance to doing anything about it, is the determination of a number of state governments to take action on their own.
2017-08-28.headline_main: States Dare to Think Big on Climate Change

2017-08-28.abstract: Forty percent of all undergraduates go to community colleges, and many can’t afford to go full-time.
2017-08-28.snippet: Forty percent of all undergraduates go to community colleges, and many can’t afford to go full-time.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: You might think the typical college student lives in a state of bliss, spending each day moving among classes, parties and extracurricular activities. But the reality is that an increasingly small population of undergraduates enjoys that kind of life.

2017-08-28.abstract: President Trump is pushing to increase production on federal lands.
2017-08-28.snippet: President Trump is pushing to increase production on federal lands.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Imagine the businessman Donald Trump putting his real estate up for sale when the market was near the bottom. That’s the equivalent of what President Trump is doing with the oil and gas on our public lands. His misguided move to increase production in a soft energy market is bad for government revenues, not necessary for national security and likely to damage natural resources that millions of Americans use and enjoy.
2017-08-28.headline_main: The Rush to Develop Oil and Gas We Don’t Need

2017-08-28.abstract: The marcher’s chant in Charlottesville really meant, “You will not take away our historical right to exclude.”
2017-08-28.snippet: The marcher’s chant in Charlottesville really meant, “You will not take away our historical right to exclude.”
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: When white nationalists converged in Charlottesville, Va., ostensibly to protest the removal of a statue of Robert E. Lee, they chanted, “You will not replace us,” and “Jews will not replace us.” But why were Jews a target of a neo-Confederate action, and who was the more generalized ‘you’?
2017-08-28.headline_main: White ‘Power’ and the Fear of Replacement

2017-08-28.abstract: The collapse of Soviet Communism led the United States into triumphalist error about its destiny as the global superpower.
2017-08-28.snippet: The collapse of Soviet Communism led the United States into triumphalist error about its destiny as the global superpower.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: The Cold War as a system of states ended on a cold and gray December day in Moscow in 1991, when Mikhail Gorbachev signed the Soviet Union out of existence. Communism itself, in its Marxist-Leninist form, had ceased to exist as a practical ideal for how to organize society.
2017-08-28.headline_main: The Cold War and America’s Delusion of Victory

2017-08-28.headline_main: Australia’s Immigration Chief Defends Cutting Support for Some Asylum Seekers

2017-08-28.abstract: Mr. Parks, perhaps more than any mid-20th-century photographer, understood how film and television conditioned the contemporary eye and mind.
2017-08-28.snippet: Mr. Parks, perhaps more than any mid-20th-century photographer, understood how film and television conditioned the contemporary eye and mind.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: When Gordon Parks photographed Duke Ellington during a television appearance in 1960, he took a series of photographs as the musician’s image flickered across control room monitors. These striking pictures would mark the beginning of Mr. Parks’s long, if relatively forgotten, relationship with television. Over the next 25 years, he directed several television documentaries and films, including a drama based on Solomon Northup’s autobiography, “Twelve Years a Slave.”
2017-08-28.headline_main: The Cinematic Images of Gordon Parks

2017-08-28.abstract: Analysts say that both sides gave ground, ending one of the worst diplomatic flare-ups between the nuclear-armed Asian rivals in decades.
2017-08-28.snippet: Analysts say that both sides gave ground, ending one of the worst diplomatic flare-ups between the nuclear-armed Asian rivals in decades.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India and China agreed on Monday to back away from their confrontation over a tiny slice of territory high in the Himalayas, easing tensions between the world’s two most populous countries.
2017-08-28.headline_main: China and India Agree to Ease Tensions in Border Dispute

2017-08-28.abstract: The Trump administration has switched sides from its predecessor in two important cases, a practice that in the past has prompted testy exchanges with the justices.

It has twice switched sides in important Supreme Court cases, on workers’ rights and voting rolls, abandoning the positions of the previous administration for ones favored by conservatives.

2017-08-28.abstract: Scientists say warm waters and stagnant winds in the upper atmosphere built a monster of a storm. Whether climate change is to blame is less clear.
2017-08-28.snippet: Scientists say warm waters and stagnant winds in the upper atmosphere built a monster of a storm. Whether climate change is to blame is less clear.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Scientists say the effects of Hurricane Harvey, which has been stalled over the Texas Gulf Coast since Friday and dumped more than 20 inches of rain in some areas, were worsened by a lethal confluence of meteorological events: warm water in the Gulf of Mexico that intensified the rainfall, and a lack of winds in the upper atmosphere that could have steered Harvey away from land.
2017-08-28.headline_main: How Hurricane Harvey Became So Destructive

2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: SHEEP OUTNUMBER PEOPLE in New Zealand, and for centuries, that was also true in the Cotswolds, the seat of England’s wool industry. Its merchants became fabulously wealthy, building some of the loveliest manors in the country’s southwest. Their distinctive gabled roofs still peek over the high hedges that line the winding roads.

2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: More than three decades ago, I fell in love with the first minivan I spotted parked in my Brooklyn neighborhood. Though I was never a “soccer mom,” I travel as if there were no stores at my destination, and here was a car that could carry half a household. And I loved sitting up high, able to see beyond the car in front of me.

2017-08-28.abstract: Mount Everest, the Chang Tang Plateau and the Sahara are among the landscapes captured by the photographer, filmmaker — and skier.
2017-08-28.snippet: Mount Everest, the Chang Tang Plateau and the Sahara are among the landscapes captured by the photographer, filmmaker — and skier.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: The professional photographer and filmmaker Jimmy Chin, 43, originally began taking photos as a means to support his mountain-climbing habit. As an adventure photographer, he has since accompanied the climber Ed Viesturs and the filmmaker David Breashears to the top of Mount Everest, trekked unsupported across 300 miles of the Chang Tang Plateau in Tibet and was a member of the first American team to ski down from the top of Everest. His work has been published in National Geographic and The New York Times Magazine, and his film “Meru,” documenting his pioneering ascent up Meru Peak in the Himalayas with two other climbers, won the Audience Award at the Sundance Film Festival in 2015. He counts landscape paintings from the Song dynasty in China and Chinese calligraphy, which he says is “about balance and use of space,” among his artistic influences in capturing vast landscapes, often with a person in them for context. The following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Chin.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Want to Take Great Travel Pictures? Jimmy Chin Has Advice

2017-08-28.abstract: How an epic hiking and packrafting trip on Kodiak Island connected us to the earth and our collective past.
2017-08-28.snippet: How an epic hiking and packrafting trip on Kodiak Island connected us to the earth and our collective past.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: I awoke to the dull ache of my blistered heel, sore back, and the chilled morning air inside the tent. Once the stiffness of the night’s sleep abated, I was overcome by the weight of the silence surrounding me.
2017-08-28.headline_main: 130 Miles, 8 Days, 1 Spellbound Photographer on Kodiak Island

2017-08-28.abstract: Work on a huge sandstone slab with fossils of the enigmatic Utahraptor is stalled for lack of money. But the team hopes public support can get it back on track.
2017-08-28.snippet: Work on a huge sandstone slab with fossils of the enigmatic Utahraptor is stalled for lack of money. But the team hopes public support can get it back on track.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Millions of years ago, on a mud flat somewhere in Cretaceous Utah, a group of Utahraptors made a grave mistake: They tried to hunt near quicksand. The pack’s poor fortune has given modern paleontologists an opportunity to decode the giant raptor — its appearance, growth and behavior — but only if they can raise the money.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Utah Paleontologists Turn to Crowdfunding for Raptor Project

2017-08-28.abstract: A community in Sikkim is abandoning the mountains, and with them an incredibly harsh life. Documenting their world captures it before it disappears forever.
2017-08-28.snippet: A community in Sikkim is abandoning the mountains, and with them an incredibly harsh life. Documenting their world captures it before it disappears forever.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: For hundreds of years, nomadic Dokpa yak herders moved between the high-altitude Tibetan Plateau and the Himalayan valleys of Sikkim, following migration patterns that were crucial to their culture and their livestock. Yaks had the opportunity to breed beyond their own gene pool; young people could meet potential spouses from a wide variety of families; Dokpas ran lucrative cross-border trade operations and visited sacred places where they performed important Buddhist rituals. With the outbreak of hostilities between India and China in 1962, however, the frontier between India and Tibet was sealed. Dokpa migration routes were severed and families were trapped on whichever side of the border they happened to be on when it was closed.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Yak Herders’ Vanishing Way of Life

2017-08-28.abstract: A nonstop journey supplies a close-up view of a family and the world they explore.
2017-08-28.snippet: A nonstop journey supplies a close-up view of a family and the world they explore.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: When you are a child, time has a way of unspooling slowly, purely set to our natural rhythm. As we grow older, time is punctuated by appointments and alarm clocks, and we forget how to live at our own pace.
2017-08-28.headline_main: This Family’s Road Trip Never Ends

2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Early in the night at the 34th annual MTV Video Music Awards, the genial pop singer Ed Sheeran was in the middle of a sober performance of “Shape of You” when, quite jarringly, the impish rapper Lil Uzi Vert crept onstage and joined in. Soon, the men were performing Uzi’s dizzying “XO Tour Llif3,” Mr. Sheeran singing grimly and Lil Uzi Vert working the stage like a catwalk while bleating out his lyrics. In the audience, a camera caught the comically expressive rapper Cardi B with an Austin Powers-esque look of amused shock.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Pop Star Egos Are Pushed Aside at Wacky, Socially Aware MTV V.M.A.s

By the time she came in to read for the part of Mama Darleena in Philip Dawkins’s drama “Charm,” Ms. Caldwell had been in dozens of films, television shows, musicals and plays. She’d performed at the Moulin Rouge in Paris, played a small part in Maya Angelou’s “Down in the Delta” and had a role in the BET mini-series “The Book of Negroes.”

2017-08-28.abstract: A new study suggests horses lost all but a single toe per foot as they evolved larger bodies and longer legs millions of years ago.
2017-08-28.snippet: A new study suggests horses lost all but a single toe per foot as they evolved larger bodies and longer legs millions of years ago.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: All four-limbed, land-based vertebrates came from a common ancestor with legs that ended in five toes. Over time, many animals lost some of their digits: Hippos, rhinos and camels have four, three and two toes on each leg. But only one living group of animals ended up with a single toe per foot: the group containing modern horses.
2017-08-28.headline_main: How Horses Got Their Hooves

2017-08-28.abstract: “Game of Thrones” notwithstanding, this summer was a bit slow. Not so in the next couple of months, when loads of our favorites come roaring back.
2017-08-28.snippet: “Game of Thrones” notwithstanding, this summer was a bit slow. Not so in the next couple of months, when loads of our favorites come roaring back.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: There was no Show of the Summer this year. Sure, “Game of Thrones” is very popular, but it’s a returning show whose fame was well established — it wasn’t somehow suddenly zeitgeisty. Compare that to “Stranger Things,” last year’s Show of the Summer. For a minute it seemed as if Netflix’s “GLOW” might be the big break-out, and while it was well received (I certainly loved it), the show’s buzz-cycle felt super short: We all talked about it for three days, and then never again. Summer 2017, feel free to see yourself out.

2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A German couple walked into their apartment building in Harlem one warm evening in 1973. There were shouts, screams, and two strangers ran out — muggers. They took off down the street.
2017-08-28.headline_main: In Pursuit of Influence (and Muggers): Denny Farrell’s 40 Years in Politics

2017-08-28.abstract: Kristen Arnett will celebrate the publication of her debut short-story collection at her local 7-Eleven.

2017-08-28.abstract: Lower overheads and greater opportunities for work-life balance are drawing city chefs to New Jersey and Long Island.
2017-08-28.snippet: Lower overheads and greater opportunities for work-life balance are drawing city chefs to New Jersey and Long Island.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Ben Pollinger made his name as a chef in the grand kitchens of Manhattan, but all the while, he was living in Bergen County, driving into the city from New Jersey. Now, like so many other chefs who are looking for opportunity, lower occupancy costs and a chance to balance their personal and professional lives, Mr. Pollinger is working farther afield.

2017-08-28.snippet: Florence Fabricant shares details on the New York openings she’s most excited about.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Fall is a time for fresh starts, and there’s something satisfying about seeing veteran chefs break out with restaurants of their own. That’s why Frenchette and Scampi are among the places I’m most looking forward to this season.
2017-08-28.headline_main: In Fall’s New Restaurants, Fresh Starts and Simple Pleasures

2017-08-28.abstract: The arrival of new cast members confirms just how good Lucas Hnath’s play is.
2017-08-28.snippet: The arrival of new cast members confirms just how good Lucas Hnath’s play is.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Like most critics, I thought “A Doll’s House, Part 2,” the what-if sequel to Ibsen by Lucas Hnath, was already great when it opened in April. But a play’s true greatness may hinge on how well it absorbs, or reshapes itself around, the succession of casts that enact it.
2017-08-28.headline_main: For ‘A Doll’s House, Part 2,’ the Second Time’s Also a Charm

The offbeat, candy-packed ice creams will get a tweak in texture, becoming creamier and smoother.

2017-08-28.abstract: Examining how a disaster can affect the overall economy, we see why financial markets and economic forecasters are relatively sanguine.
2017-08-28.snippet: Examining how a disaster can affect the overall economy, we see why financial markets and economic forecasters are relatively sanguine.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Harvey is a disaster of monumental proportions that will destroy vast amounts of property and upend millions of lives. But it also appears that the overall economic toll, at least for the United States as a whole, will be modest. And that surprising fact offers important lessons about how the modern economy works.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Markets Are Signaling That Hurricane Harvey Won’t Crush the Economy

2017-08-28.snippet: Jamie Hawkesworth is the subject of a new show in Amsterdam that encompasses much of his work over the last decade.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: The 30-year-old Suffolk-born photographer Jamie Hawkesworth started by studying forensic science at Preston University in Lancashire, in England’s northwest. But it was only when he picked up a camera to document reconstructions of crime scenes for the course that he realized his true passion. “It was like a switch went off,” he says. “That’s when I realized there was so much potential in photography. I quickly fell in love with taking pictures.”
2017-08-28.headline_main: One Photographer’s Personal (and Visual) Journey

Golden, a former logistics manager at a Target store, fires up the computer in his home office in northern Florida and does what he has done for years: Put on bets that Wall Street’s index of volatility, the VIX, will keep falling.

2017-08-28.abstract: Chelsea Local opens on the lower level of the building, a new food market comes to Brooklyn and quick pastas from a Del Posto chef.
2017-08-28.snippet: Chelsea Local opens on the lower level of the building, a new food market comes to Brooklyn and quick pastas from a Del Posto chef.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: From the beginning, Chelsea Market has been in a state of flux, with a periodic turnover of vendors and makeover of retail space. Chelsea Local is the latest expansion, in what was partly a storage area for Manhattan Fruit Exchange. A broad new staircase in the center of the market leads to the 13,000-square-foot space, which offers ingredients like olive oil, fresh mushrooms and herbs, pasture-raised meat or a hunk of clothbound Cheddar to take home. Jamestown, the company that runs the market, designed Chelsea Local with city shoppers in mind. Manhattan Fruit Exchange and Buon’Italia are now on this level, and Dickson’s Farmstand Meats has an additional counter here. Saxelby Cheesemongers, Heatonist for hot sauces and Ronnybrook Farm Dairy also have stands: Chelsea Local, lower level, Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (West 15th Street), chelseamarket.com.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Chelsea Market Expands With a Food-Focused Floor

2017-08-28.abstract: Historians have long debated Lee’s place in American history, and that battle continues today.
2017-08-28.snippet: Historians have long debated Lee’s place in American history, and that battle continues today.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: In the Band’s popular song “The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down,” an ex-Confederate soldier refers to Robert E. Lee as “the very best.” It is difficult to think of another song that mentions a general by name. But Lee has always occupied a unique place in the national imagination. The ups and downs of his reputation reflect changes in key elements of Americans’ historical consciousness — how we understand race relations, the causes and consequences of the Civil War and the nature of the good society.
2017-08-28.headline_main: The Making and the Breaking of the Legend of Robert E. Lee

2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Harvey may inflict as much as $30 billion in damages on homeowners, according to preliminary estimates. But only 40 percent of that total may be covered by insurance — and of that, the federal government will bear the biggest liability.

2017-08-28.abstract: New York Times readers, many from across Texas and other areas that have been hit by hurricanes, said this storm evoked painful memories.
2017-08-28.snippet: New York Times readers, many from across Texas and other areas that have been hit by hurricanes, said this storm evoked painful memories.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: People who live in the areas hit hardest by the hurricane that pounded Houston over the weekend have long been used to major storms blowing in off the Gulf of Mexico. But this storm, and the flooding that came after, was unlike any other.
2017-08-28.headline_main: ‘The Only Thing to Do Is Wait.’ Readers React to the Texas Hurricane

2017-08-28.abstract: Hurricane Harvey has us wading from house to house in our Texas suburb to see what nature and humanity have wrought.
2017-08-28.snippet: Hurricane Harvey has us wading from house to house in our Texas suburb to see what nature and humanity have wrought.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Overnight, everyone in our neighborhood has become Ned Merrill, the protagonist in John Cheever’s short story “The Swimmer.” We live in a Houston suburb where most houses come equipped with backyard pools. With the arrival of Hurricane Harvey, the pools have been made not just redundant, but nearly contiguous. While we are not (yet) like Merrill — swimming from house to house, having drinks and learning about one another — the storm has us wading from house to house, taking the measure of what nature, and we ourselves, have wrought.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Swimming in Houston

2017-08-28.abstract: On Tuesday, the public ferry system is adding a route with stops in Queens. But the location of a dock in Astoria has kayakers worrying about safety.
2017-08-28.snippet: On Tuesday, the public ferry system is adding a route with stops in Queens. But the location of a dock in Astoria has kayakers worrying about safety.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: Three days before New York City’s commuter ferry service was due to make its first run from a new floating terminal in Astoria, the dock in Hallets Cove was surrounded by a curious hazard — novice kayakers struggling to avoid capsizing in the murky East River.
2017-08-28.headline_main: NYC Ferry Is Expanding Again, but Not Without Growing Pains

2017-08-28.abstract: The likely need for a multibillion-dollar emergency relief measure creates another urgent issue for Congress to address in what was already expected to be a busy September.
2017-08-28.snippet: The likely need for a multibillion-dollar emergency relief measure creates another urgent issue for Congress to address in what was already expected to be a busy September.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The rising floodwaters of Tropical Storm Harvey will add another pressing issue to an already tense fiscal showdown that faces Congress as lawmakers return next week from a monthlong recess.
2017-08-28.headline_main: For Congress, Storm Adds Another Urgent Issue to a Full Plate

2017-08-28.abstract: The George R. Brown Convention Center, in downtown Houston, is a hub of the enormous relief operation as the city confronts catastrophic flooding.
2017-08-28.snippet: The George R. Brown Convention Center, in downtown Houston, is a hub of the enormous relief operation as the city confronts catastrophic flooding.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The rescued are almost always wet when they arrive — slick, shuffling and staggering after hours in the rain. They are met with blankets and a security check, dry clothes and green cots. And then there is a feeling of relief that, for the moment, they have left the floodwaters behind.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Coffee and Cots as Houston Houses Thousands in a Convention Center

2017-08-28.abstract: After a fire in Borough Park, Brooklyn, left a husband and wife dead, neighbors recalled the caring nature of the victims, who would often give gifts and volunteer their time.
2017-08-28.snippet: After a fire in Borough Park, Brooklyn, left a husband and wife dead, neighbors recalled the caring nature of the victims, who would often give gifts and volunteer their time.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: The second-story windows of the sage green house on 44th Street look out over a peaked porch roof in Borough Park, Brooklyn. On Monday, they were charred and without glass. Neighbors clustered below, whispering in English and Yiddish about how hours before some had watched helplessly as an early-morning blaze tore through the home in the largely Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish community. As the fire burned, a teenager who lived there had stood on that roof, begging someone to save her parents, trapped inside.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Jewish Community Mourns Couple Killed in House Fire

2017-08-28.abstract: As the Supreme Court prepared to hear the case, an appeals court considered who may be barred from entering in the meantime. The judges were more circumspect about refugees.
2017-08-28.snippet: As the Supreme Court prepared to hear the case, an appeals court considered who may be barred from entering in the meantime. The judges were more circumspect about refugees.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the latest arguments over President Trump’s travel ban, a three-judge panel of a federal appeals court in Seattle indicated on Monday that it would continue allowing grandparents and other relatives of United States residents to travel here from six predominantly Muslim countries.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Appeals Court Appears Inclined to Exempt Relatives From Travel Ban

2017-08-28.abstract: Don’t expect him to become a politician, but the Apple C.E.O. sees gaps in governmental social policies that he believes companies like his are obliged to help fill.
2017-08-28.snippet: Don’t expect him to become a politician, but the Apple C.E.O. sees gaps in governmental social policies that he believes companies like his are obliged to help fill.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — “The reality is that government, for a long period of time, has for whatever set of reasons become less functional and isn’t working at the speed that it once was. And so it does fall, I think, not just on business but on all other areas of society to step up.”
2017-08-28.headline_main: Apple’s Tim Cook Barnstorms for ‘Moral Responsibility’

2017-08-28.abstract: Officials from France, Germany, Italy and Spain met with leaders from Chad, Niger and Libya to discuss ways to stop the flow of migrants.
2017-08-28.snippet: Officials from France, Germany, Italy and Spain met with leaders from Chad, Niger and Libya to discuss ways to stop the flow of migrants.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Measures intended to stop migrants from trying to cross the Mediterranean were at the center of discussions among four European leaders who met in Paris with the leaders of three African countries on Monday.
2017-08-28.headline_main: European Leaders Look to Africa to Stem Migration

2017-08-28.abstract: The flooding from Tropical Storm Harvey that has turned neighborhoods into lakes is just the start of a disaster that will take years to overcome.
2017-08-28.snippet: The flooding from Tropical Storm Harvey that has turned neighborhoods into lakes is just the start of a disaster that will take years to overcome.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As one of the most destructive storms in the nation’s history pummeled southeast Texas for a fourth day, forecasts on Tuesday morning called for still more rain, making clear that catastrophic flooding that had turned neighborhoods into lakes was just the start of a disaster that would take years to overcome.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Deluged Texas Braces for More Rain, and Years of Recovery

2017-08-28.abstract: If your home was damaged because of flooding and is covered through the National Flood Insurance Program, FEMA offers these steps to file a claim.
2017-08-28.snippet: If your home was damaged because of flooding and is covered through the National Flood Insurance Program, FEMA offers these steps to file a claim.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: The National Flood Insurance Program was created by Congress to provide flood insurance to property owners. Homeowners in areas designated as 100-year flood zones are supposed to hold policies from the federal program. The Federal Emergency Management Agency is telling homeowners who are covered by the program to take these steps to file a claim if flooding has damaged their home:
2017-08-28.headline_main: How to File a Claim for Flood Damage

2017-08-28.abstract: We didn’t have the capacity to transport and house millions of evacuees.
2017-08-28.snippet: We didn’t have the capacity to transport and house millions of evacuees.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: As the rains from Tropical Storm Harvey continue to pound Houston, stranding thousands of people in their homes, a question has emerged: Should local officials, particularly Mayor Sylvester Turner, have ordered mandatory evacuations?
2017-08-28.headline_main: Houston’s Mayor Was Right to Not Evacuate

2017-08-28.abstract: With Hurricane Harvey bearing down, Mayor Sylvester Turner had to weigh the risks of sheltering in place against the dangers of a mandatory evacuation that would hopelessly clog highways. Not everyone agrees that he made the right call.
2017-08-28.snippet: With Hurricane Harvey bearing down, Mayor Sylvester Turner had to weigh the risks of sheltering in place against the dangers of a mandatory evacuation that would hopelessly clog highways. Not everyone agrees that he made the right call.
2017-08-28.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Phyllis Ullman, 73, had been evacuated from her flooded neighborhood Monday morning, and was visibly shaken as she sat in the back seat of a rescuer’s pickup truck speeding through the spitting rain. You can’t argue with Mother Nature, but she had strong words for Mayor Sylvester Turner’s decision not to issue a mandatory evacuation order for Houston, the nation’s fourth-largest city.
2017-08-28.headline_main: Houston Mayor’s No-Win Dilemma: Whether to Tell Residents to Stay or Go

2017-08-29.abstract: Terms like “500-year flood” and “100-year flood” are used as shorthand by government officials and actuaries, but they can confuse the public.
2017-08-29.snippet: Terms like “500-year flood” and “100-year flood” are used as shorthand by government officials and actuaries, but they can confuse the public.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: Terms like “500-year flood” and “100-year flood” are used as shorthand by government officials and actuaries, but they can confuse the public.
2017-08-29.headline_main: A ‘500-Year Flood’ Could Happen Again Sooner Than You Think. Here’s Why.

2017-08-29.abstract: Even before the water recedes, there are lessons to consider, including about flood mitigation and the reality of climate change.
2017-08-29.snippet: Even before the water recedes, there are lessons to consider, including about flood mitigation and the reality of climate change.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: Downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm, Harvey continues to rain rivers down on Houston and its surroundings, inundating homes and businesses and tearing apart the lives of tens of thousands of people. It is hard not to be moved by the pictures and videos of police officers and ordinary citizens in boats and inflatable rafts rescuing people from roofs and partly submerged cars, volunteering at shelters and handing out food and water to the hungry. And while the local, state and federal response appears to be going about as well as could have been expected, Harvey has already left a devastating mark on the nation’s fourth-largest city and will surely etch itself in the pantheon of great natural disasters alongside storms like Katrina and Andrew.
2017-08-29.headline_main: As Harvey Rains Down Devastation, Houston Stands Together

2017-08-29.abstract: Mr. Skrein’s departure is the first time in recent years that an actor has left a major film over whitewashing concerns.
2017-08-29.snippet: Mr. Skrein’s departure is the first time in recent years that an actor has left a major film over whitewashing concerns.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: The actor Ed Skrein said on Monday that he was backing out of a role in the forthcoming movie “Hellboy” after public criticism over his casting to play a character portrayed as Asian in the original comic book.
2017-08-29.headline_main: Ed Skrein, Facing Criticism, Backs Out of Playing Asian Character in ‘Hellboy’

2017-08-29.abstract: Many wonder if Gary D. Cohn’s and Steven Mnuchin’s real-world experience in finance has equipped them to carry out a delicate political negotiation.
2017-08-29.snippet: Many wonder if Gary D. Cohn’s and Steven Mnuchin’s real-world experience in finance has equipped them to carry out a delicate political negotiation.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gary D. Cohn and Steven Mnuchin have spent months behind closed doors with Republican congressional leaders sketching the contours of an elaborate and politically difficult tax overhaul that is President Trump’s top priority.
2017-08-29.headline_main: Two Bankers Are Selling Trump’s Tax Plan. Is Congress Buying?

2017-08-29.abstract: Because of public safety concerns, the editorial and business staff at The New York Times made coverage of the storm free to access.
2017-08-29.snippet: Because of public safety concerns, the editorial and business staff at The New York Times made coverage of the storm free to access.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Harvey approached the southeastern Texas coastline late last week, The New York Times mobilized reporters and photographers across the region. Coverage included reports of heroic rescues of families on the roofs of their homes and tallies of the rain accumulation that has left Houston at the mercy of paralyzing floods.
2017-08-29.headline_main: Why the Paywall Came Down for Hurricane Harvey

2017-08-29.abstract: The lawyer for Baquer and Siamak Namazi denounced the “cruel and unjust” decision, which could still further worsen relations with Iran.

2017-08-29.headline_main: Quotation of the Day: Deluged and Weary, Texas Braces for Years of Recovery

2017-08-29.abstract: Many trying to escape the flooding are taking animals aboard the boats and high-water vehicles they use to get to dry ground.
2017-08-29.snippet: Many trying to escape the flooding are taking animals aboard the boats and high-water vehicles they use to get to dry ground.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: When Joe Garcia spotted a rescue boat on Monday outside his flooded home in Spring, a suburb north of Houston, he pushed a plastic tub of his belongings through chest-high water and loaded it on the boat. Then he returned to his home to grab one more prized possession: Heidi, his German shepherd.
2017-08-29.headline_main: Saving Pets Is Paramount for Many Fleeing Tropical Storm Harvey

2017-08-29.abstract: Adam Perl trolls us ever so gently.
2017-08-29.snippet: Adam Perl trolls us ever so gently.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — We get a lot of different kinds of mail about the crosswords, and, as a whole, these letters reinforce my belief that if you were to ask 10 solvers for their opinions about a given puzzle, you would most likely get 10 fairly unique answers. That’s how subjective we are about our puzzles. People are always entitled to their opinions, of course. And constructors are entitled to gently troll them right back. That’s one reason Adam Perl’s puzzle made me smile today, but there are others and I’ll get to those in a minute.
2017-08-29.headline_main: Overly Inventive

2017-08-29.snippet: The British clothier, newly arrived in SoHo, is holding the line against athleisure.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: Shopping, at least in the context of this column, is a kind of performance. It has little to do with satisfying a need, or a curiosity, and more to do with cramming at the library: You take the text as it is, not as you would like it to be, and you try to take all of it in and assess it on its own merits.

2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: The “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville, Va., shocked many Americans with its unashamed and open embrace of white supremacist and Nazi ideology. It set off a passionate national discussion on how to best deal with racism and racist groups. There is an unconventional starting point: revoking the tax exemption of white supremacist groups.

2017-08-29.abstract: The president might have tried to end the war in 1967. Then came Senator John Stennis.
2017-08-29.snippet: The president might have tried to end the war in 1967. Then came Senator John Stennis.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: By the late summer of 1967, Lyndon Johnson faced a stark choice on Vietnam. His secretary of defense, Robert McNamara, had become convinced that the war was unwinnable and urged the president to announce a bombing halt to coax North Vietnam into negotiations. But the generals on the Joint Chiefs of Staff pushed back — the war was winnable, they insisted, if only the president would double down on bombing, mine the North’s main port of Haiphong harbor and add 200,000 men to the ranks, most of them destined for Vietnam.
2017-08-29.headline_main: Lyndon Johnson vs. the Hawks

2017-08-29.abstract: On the shores of Denmark, the massive Tirpitz bunker, which was built by the Nazis, is now part of a new museum. Designed by Bjarke Ingels Group, the Tirpitz Museum features exhibitions about World War II, western Denmark and a collection of Danish amber.

2017-08-29.abstract: From Silicon Valley to the White House, changing your narrative is as easy as announcing your intention to do so.
2017-08-29.snippet: From Silicon Valley to the White House, changing your narrative is as easy as announcing your intention to do so.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: Last month, the right-wing media personality Mike Cernovich announced that he was conducting a ‘‘big pivot’’ away from the fringes of the news ecosystem. The move was unexpected, as Cernovich had carved out a comfortable niche for himself — railing against coastal elites and feminism, peddling conspiracy theories and self-help books. But Cernovich appeared to have decided that it was ‘‘bad for business’’ to, for example, keep pushing rumors of pedophilia in the Democratic leadership. Instead he wanted to capitalize on the relationships he had developed with Trump-administration officials in order to present himself as a new kind of journalist.

2017-08-29.abstract: Exit velocities, launch angles, distances, ‘barrels’ — do more stats describing how a ball is hit make us smarter about baseball, or make the game more fun?
2017-08-29.snippet: Exit velocities, launch angles, distances, ‘barrels’ — do more stats describing how a ball is hit make us smarter about baseball, or make the game more fun?
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: For the casual, uninitiated baseball fan who tunes in every once in a while, this season’s home-run calls must sound as baffling as a Pentecostal sermon to an unbeliever. A baseball broadcast is, as much as anything, a string of synonyms in a familiar, comforting cadence. Words like ‘‘dinger,’’ ‘‘laser’’ and ‘‘punchado’’ take years to embed themselves into the game’s collective vocabulary, and there’s a graveyard full of home-run and strikeout calls that failed to do so or have fallen out of fashion. (My favorite among the dead: the understated yet effective ‘‘tater’’ for a home run.) Statistics have an even harder time gaining mainstream acceptance, so it must be strange for a newbie to tune in to a Yankees game this year and see Aaron Judge, baseball’s largest son, hit a towering shot into the bleachers and hear the commentator say something like, ‘‘Wow, that ball traveled out of here with an exit velocity of 115.3 miles per hour!’’
2017-08-29.headline_main: Why Are Some New Statistics Embraced and Not Others?

2017-08-29.abstract: Sophisticated computer modeling has taken district manipulation to new extremes. To fix this, courts might have to learn how to run the numbers themselves.
2017-08-29.snippet: Sophisticated computer modeling has taken district manipulation to new extremes. To fix this, courts might have to learn how to run the numbers themselves.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: In the late spring of 2011, Dale Schultz walked the short block in Madison from his State Senate office in the Wisconsin Capitol to the glass-­paneled building of Michael Best & Friedrich, a law firm with deep ties to his Republican Party. First elected in 1982, Schultz placed himself within the progressive tradition that made Wisconsin, a century ago, the birthplace of the state income tax and laws that guarantee compensation for injured workers. In the months before his visit to Michael Best, Schultz cast the lone Republican vote against a bill that stripped collective-­bargaining rights from most public employees. But if Schultz had doubts about some of his party’s priorities, he welcomed its ascendance to power. For the first time in his career, Republicans controlled the State Senate and the State Assembly as well as the governor’s office, giving them total sway over the redistricting process that follows the census taken at the beginning of each decade. ‘‘The way I saw it, reapportionment is a moment of opportunity for the ruling party,’’ Schultz told me this summer.
2017-08-29.headline_main: The New Front in the Gerrymandering Wars: Democracy vs. Math

2017-08-29.abstract: Trevor Paglen’s work reaches new heights — literally. This spring, he hopes to launch the world’s first space sculpture.
2017-08-29.snippet: Trevor Paglen’s work reaches new heights — literally. This spring, he hopes to launch the world’s first space sculpture.
2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: ‘‘Are we being watched?’’ I ask Trevor Paglen at his central Berlin studio. The prewar apartment was once surely the most surveilled place in the city, having formerly belonged to his friend Laura Poitras, the director who helped Edward Snowden go public. ‘‘We’re always being watched,’’ he replies. The space is filled with computers: Against one wall, an assistant writes code while another researches data used to train artificial intelligence. Opposite is a long credenza filled with art monographs and topped by a slightly sinister collection of objets: a Dungeons & Dragons-style dragon trophy with a shield and saber; a toy model of the stealth submarine U.S.S. Jimmy Carter; and ‘‘Black Ops’’ military patches, including some Paglen made himself. In one of them, dinosaurs of the future look up in wonder at the derelict satellites left behind by extinct humans.
2017-08-29.headline_main: Art for a Post-Surveillance Age

Climate change definitely made such an event more likely; beyond that, Houston’s total lack of zoning, complete failure to limit the amount of land paved over, made it much more vulnerable than sheer geography required.

Neither leg stayed on the ground for long; it was as if he were constantly making sure the floor was still there, that his saxophone hadn’t lifted him up and away.

2017-08-29.lead_paragraph: The classical dances of India, so laden with centuries-old traditions, keep revealing how the sociology of that intensely populous nation has been changing. I attended seven performances of the Drive East season of Indian dance and music last week at Dixon Place; each brought revelations. And I was often taken to places Indian dance had not taken me before.

Claire Chennault known as the Flying Tigers fought Japanese aggression in China. They were so successful that many people believe they were decisive in holding back Japan, eventually leading to its defeat.

2017-08-30.lead_paragraph: It’s admirable that Americans’ first instinct when disaster occurs is to open their wallets and volunteer their time. 2017-08-30.abstract: Visits to key military bases create contrasting impressions, including between service members and their commander in chief.
2017-08-30.snippet: Visits to key military bases create contrasting impressions, including between service members and their commander in chief.
2017-08-30.lead_paragraph: I’m just back from visiting all of our key air bases in Iraq, Afghanistan and along the Persian Gulf, and I find myself wrestling with two stark contrasts: the contrast between what is happening there in the air and what is happening on the ground, and the contrast between the decency of the U.S. military personnel fighting this war and how unworthy Donald Trump — who has become our divider in chief — is to be their commander in chief.

2017-08-30.abstract: The story and work of Hosam Katan, a Syrian photographer, reveals much about how coverage of the Syrian conflict has changed.
2017-08-30.snippet: The story and work of Hosam Katan, a Syrian photographer, reveals much about how coverage of the Syrian conflict has changed.
2017-08-30.lead_paragraph: When a Syrian Army sniper shot Hosam Katan in Aleppo in May 2015, Mr. Katan couldn’t feel where the bullet had hit. He hoped it wasn’t his eye or his thigh. In five years photographing the Syrian conflict, he had seen enough colleagues shot to know which wounds were fatal, and which were not. As he lay bleeding, he realized he might soon join Marie Colvin and James Foley on the list of journalists killed covering Syria’s civil war.
2017-08-30.headline_main: ‘I Am Not Useful for My Camera if I Die': A Syrian Photographer’s View

2017-08-30.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what you owe a longtime domestic employee and how to balance business interests against social harms.
2017-08-30.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what you owe a longtime domestic employee and how to balance business interests against social harms.
2017-08-30.lead_paragraph: I recently discovered that one of my live-in nannies has a serious gambling problem. Now I know why she always comes home way past curfew and is always short of money. I have never witnessed her stealing anything from us, and our children are very attached to her, but she is four years away from retirement, and I fear the day will come when she realizes she has no savings and will do something drastic.
2017-08-30.headline_main: My Nanny Has a Gambling Problem. Can I Fire Her?

2017-08-30.abstract: His presidency has changed the rules of influence in the nation’s capital — and spawned a new breed of lobbyist on K Street.
2017-08-30.snippet: His presidency has changed the rules of influence in the nation’s capital — and spawned a new breed of lobbyist on K Street.
2017-08-30.lead_paragraph: As for so many other people, election night did not pan out quite the way Robert Stryk expected. Stryk began the night slumped in a Morton’s steakhouse in downtown Washington, tuning out the guests at his watch party to type out the campaign announcement of a buddy who — in the wake of Donald J. Trump’s all-but-certain defeat and the Republican Party implosion that was sure to follow — planned to make a long-shot bid for chairman of the Republican National Committee. He ended it by closing down the bar at the Mayflower Hotel, and after the race was called, giddily marching down Connecticut Avenue with his friends as they chanted, ‘‘Make America Great Again!’’
2017-08-30.headline_main: How to Get Rich in Trump’s Washington

2017-08-30.abstract: Beloved authors and illustrators reflect on their best and worst teachers, new approaches to old subjects and how to conquer bullies — and underwear.
2017-08-30.snippet: Beloved authors and illustrators reflect on their best and worst teachers, new approaches to old subjects and how to conquer bullies — and underwear.

2017-08-30.abstract: The chief brand officer of the ride-share company on diversity statistics and trusting brands.
2017-08-30.snippet: The chief brand officer of the ride-share company on diversity statistics and trusting brands.
2017-08-30.lead_paragraph: In June, you were hired as chief brand officer for Uber, a job you took after months of controversy over legal, workplace and personnel issues at the company. You’ve said you want to ‘‘humanize’’ Uber. Do you think that brands can have human characteristics? I do think brands are like people. The product does not exist without an emotion connected to it. You’ve birthed life into a product and created a personality. You can look at any industry and say: ‘‘Why this sneaker over that sneaker? Why this soda over that one?’’ That’s what brands are — they’re living, breathing things that are sometimes very happy, sometimes sad, sometimes angry. It’s our job as marketers and brand professionals to nurture the brand and calm it down when it’s angry and to encourage when it’s trying to grow.
2017-08-30.headline_main: Bozoma Saint John Wants to Humanize Uber

2017-08-30.abstract: One of New York’s last isolated frontiers, sleepy Sullivan County has finally found its place in the sun.
2017-08-30.snippet: One of New York’s last isolated frontiers, sleepy Sullivan County has finally found its place in the sun.
2017-08-30.lead_paragraph: Sullivan County — located two hours northwest of Manhattan in the Upper Delaware Valley of the Catskill Mountains — has long been a source of bounty for the city. In the 1800s, its surrounding bluestone rock was used to create many of N.Y.C.’s sidewalks, and its farms and dairies now supply many of the city’s best restaurants with organic vegetables and cheeses. Unlike more densely settled, gentrified areas outside the city, such as the Hudson River Valley or the Hamptons, this corner of the state feels lost in time, a cluster of tiny two-block hamlets that follow the twists of the Delaware River. Famous for its fly-fishing, it was once home to a number of 19th-century outdoors clubs (some of which still exist today) on the Beaverkill, a trout-stocked tributary of the Delaware. Later, an absence of trains linking Sullivan County to Manhattan, along with a lack of sophisticated hotels and restaurants, preserved the area’s untrammeled remoteness, leaving it largely underdeveloped and undervisited.
2017-08-30.headline_main: What to Do (and Where to Stay) in the Western Catskills
